title: Convergence of finite element right-hand-side computation from finite difference data
summary: This work presents two integration methods for field transfer in computational aeroacoustics and in coupled field problems, using the finite element method to solve the acoustic field. Firstly, a high-order Gaussian quadrature computes the finite element right-hand side. In contrast, the (flow) field provided by the finite difference mesh is mapped by higher-order B-Splines or a Lagrangian function. Secondly, the cut-cell or supermesh integration with geometric clipping. For each method, the accuracy, performance characteristics, and computational complexity are analyzed. As a reference, the trapezoidal integration rule was computed from the finite difference results. The high-order quadrature converges as the B-Spline interpolation order increases, and the finite difference results and mesh resolutions are consistent. The supermesh approach eliminates interpolation and approximation errors at the grid-to-mesh level and improves accuracy. This behaviour is universal for smooth or strongly oscillating field quantities, which will be shown in a comparative study between the Lighthill-like source term and the source term of the perturbed convective wave equation for subsonic flows.

AI.tldr: Two integration methods for field transfer in computational aeroacoustics: high-order Gaussian quadrature with B-Spline/Lagrangian mapping, and cut-cell/supermesh integration with geometric clipping.
AI.motivation: To develop accurate and efficient field transfer methods between different computational grids (finite difference flow field to finite element acoustic field) in coupled aeroacoustic problems.
AI.method: 1) High-order Gaussian quadrature with B-Spline/Lagrangian interpolation mapping from finite difference mesh to finite element mesh. 2) Cut-cell/supermesh integration with geometric clipping that eliminates interpolation errors.
AI.result: High-order quadrature converges with increasing B-Spline order and consistent mesh resolutions. Supermesh approach eliminates grid-to-mesh interpolation errors and improves accuracy for both smooth and oscillating fields.
AI.conclusion: Both methods provide effective field transfer solutions, with supermesh integration offering superior accuracy by eliminating interpolation errors, validated through comparative study of Lighthill-like and perturbed convective wave equation source terms.

title: A low-order hybrid method for the variable-density incompressible Navier-Stokes equations
summary: In this work we introduce and analyse a new low-order method for the variable-density incompressible Navier-Stokes equations. The main novelty of the proposed method lies in the support of general meshes, possibly including polygonal or polyhedral elements as well as non-matching interfaces. We carry out a complete analysis, showing stability, existence and uniqueness of a discrete solution, and convergence of the latter to a suitably defined weak solution of the continuous problem. Numerical tests validate the theoretical results.

AI.tldr: A new low-order method for variable-density incompressible Navier-Stokes equations that supports general meshes including polygonal/polyhedral elements and non-matching interfaces.
AI.motivation: To develop a numerical method that can handle complex geometries and mesh configurations for variable-density incompressible flows, overcoming limitations of traditional mesh structures.
AI.method: A low-order numerical method designed to work on general meshes, supporting polygonal/polyhedral elements and non-matching interfaces. The method includes complete stability analysis and proof of solution existence/uniqueness.
AI.result: Theoretical analysis shows stability, existence and uniqueness of discrete solutions, with convergence to weak solutions of the continuous problem. Numerical tests validate the theoretical findings.
AI.conclusion: The proposed method successfully handles complex mesh configurations while maintaining mathematical rigor, providing a practical tool for simulating variable-density incompressible flows on general computational domains.

title: Variance Reduction in the Fokker-Planck Particle Method for Rarefied Gases using Quasi-Random Numbers
summary: The Fokker-Planck (FP) particle method accelerates rarefied-gas simulations by replacing the binary collisions of the commonly used Direct Simulation Monte Carlo (DSMC) method with a drift=diffusion process. Like all particle methods, the FP method is inherently stochastic, which leads to statistical fluctuations in macroscopic quantities and necessitates large particle numbers for accurate results. In this work, we investigate the use of quasi-random numbers, which sample distributions more evenly and thereby reduce the variance. To preserve the low-discrepancy structure across time steps, we employ the Array Randomized Quasi-Monte Carlo (Array-RQMC) technique. We combine the FP method with Array-RQMC and compare it in homogeneous and inhomogeneous problems with other commonly used variance-reduction techniques. The proposed FP-Array-RQMC approach achieves improved convergence rates compared with pseudo-random sampling and yields smaller estimator errors for sufficiently large particle numbers.

AI.tldr: FP-Array-RQMC method combines Fokker-Planck particle method with Array Randomized Quasi-Monte Carlo to reduce statistical fluctuations in rarefied-gas simulations, achieving better convergence than pseudo-random sampling.
AI.motivation: The Fokker-Planck particle method suffers from statistical fluctuations due to inherent stochasticity, requiring large particle numbers for accuracy. Variance reduction is needed to improve efficiency.
AI.method: Combine FP particle method with Array-RQMC technique using quasi-random numbers that sample distributions more evenly, preserving low-discrepancy structure across time steps.
AI.result: FP-Array-RQMC achieves improved convergence rates compared to pseudo-random sampling and yields smaller estimator errors for sufficiently large particle numbers in both homogeneous and inhomogeneous problems.
AI.conclusion: The proposed FP-Array-RQMC approach effectively reduces variance in rarefied-gas simulations, outperforming other common variance-reduction techniques.

title: High-Order Symmetric Positive Interior Quadrature Rules on Two and Three Dimensional Domains
summary: Fully symmetric positive interior (f-SPI) quadrature rules are key building blocks for high-order discretizations of partial differential equations, yet high-degree rules with few nodes remain scarce on reference elements commonly used in mesh generation. We construct new f-SPI rules on the square, cube, prism, and pyramid by coupling a variable parameterization that enforces positivity and interiority with an efficient Levenberg-Marquardt optimization and a symmetry-aware node-reduction strategy that eliminates and collapses orbits, allowing transitions between symmetry types. The resulting rules achieve degrees up to 77 on the square, 45 on the cube, and 30 on the prism and pyramid, and for most degrees use fewer nodes than previously published f-SPI quadrature rules. Verification tests demonstrate comparable accuracy to existing rules. Complete node and weight data are also provided.

AI.tldr: New fully symmetric positive interior quadrature rules with high degrees and fewer nodes developed for square, cube, prism, and pyramid elements using optimization and symmetry-aware reduction.
AI.motivation: High-degree fully symmetric positive interior (f-SPI) quadrature rules are essential for high-order PDE discretizations but remain scarce on common reference elements used in mesh generation.
AI.method: Combined variable parameterization enforcing positivity and interiority with Levenberg-Marquardt optimization and symmetry-aware node-reduction strategy that eliminates/collapses orbits to transition between symmetry types.
AI.result: Achieved degrees up to 77 on square, 45 on cube, and 30 on prism and pyramid, with fewer nodes than previous f-SPI rules for most degrees, while maintaining comparable accuracy.
AI.conclusion: Successfully constructed new high-degree f-SPI quadrature rules with reduced node counts for common reference elements, providing complete node and weight data for practical use.

title: Differentiable quantum-trajectory simulation of Lindblad dynamics for QGP transport-coefficient inference
summary: We study parameter estimation for the transport coefficients of the quark-gluon plasma by differentiating open-quantum-system-based Monte Carlo simulations of quarkonium suppression. The underlying simulator requires solving a Lindblad equation in a large Hilbert space, which makes parameter estimation computationally expensive. We approach the problem using gradient-based optimization. Specifically, we apply the score-function gradient estimator to differentiate through discrete jump sampling in the Monte Carlo wave-function algorithm used to solve the Lindblad equation. The resulting stochastic gradient estimator exhibits sufficiently low variance and can still be estimated in an embarrassingly parallel manner, enabling efficient scaling of the simulations. We implement this gradient estimator in the existing open-source quarkonium suppression code QTraj. To demonstrate its utility for parameter estimation, we infer the two transport coefficients $\hatκ$ and $\hatγ$ using gradient-based optimization on synthetic nuclear modification factor data.

AI.tldr: Differentiating open-quantum-system Monte Carlo simulations for quarkonium suppression to estimate quark-gluon plasma transport coefficients using gradient-based optimization with score-function gradient estimator.
AI.motivation: Parameter estimation for quark-gluon plasma transport coefficients is computationally expensive due to the need to solve Lindblad equations in large Hilbert spaces for quarkonium suppression simulations.
AI.method: Apply score-function gradient estimator to differentiate through discrete jump sampling in Monte Carlo wave-function algorithm used to solve Lindblad equations. Implement in existing QTraj code for parallel stochastic gradient estimation.
AI.result: The gradient estimator exhibits low variance and enables efficient parallel scaling. Demonstrated utility by inferring transport coefficients κ̂ and γ̂ using gradient-based optimization on synthetic nuclear modification factor data.
AI.conclusion: Gradient-based optimization with score-function gradient estimator enables efficient parameter estimation for quark-gluon plasma transport coefficients from quarkonium suppression simulations, overcoming computational challenges of Lindblad equation solutions.

title: A simple proof of the Uniqueness of blow-up solutions of mean field equations
comment: arXiv admin note: text overlap with arXiv:2401.12057 by other authors
summary: For a regular mean field equation defined on a compact Riemann surface, an important work of Bartolucci-Jevnikar-Lee-Yang \cite{bart-4} proved a uniqueness theorem for blow-up solutions under non-degeneracy assumptions. However, the proof is highly nontrivial and challenging to read. In this article, we not only provide a simple proof for the regular equation but also extend our proof to the case of singular equations with negative singular poles. Our proof supplements what is not written in a recent outstanding work by Bartolucci-Yang-Zhang \cite{byz-1}.

AI.tldr: The paper provides a simpler proof for uniqueness of blow-up solutions to regular mean field equations on Riemann surfaces, and extends this to singular equations with negative singular poles.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to simplify the complex proof by Bartolucci-Jevnikar-Lee-Yang for uniqueness of blow-up solutions to regular mean field equations, and to extend this result to singular equations with negative singular poles, addressing gaps in recent work by Bartolucci-Yang-Zhang.
AI.method: The authors develop a simpler proof approach for the regular mean field equation case, then extend this methodology to handle singular equations with negative singular poles, supplementing what was missing in previous work.
AI.result: The paper successfully provides a simplified proof for uniqueness of blow-up solutions to regular mean field equations and extends this uniqueness result to singular equations with negative singular poles.
AI.conclusion: The work offers a more accessible proof for an important result in mean field equations while extending the theory to singular cases, filling gaps in the existing literature and making the results more approachable to researchers.

title: Plasma-Enhanced Germination in North Indian Wheat
summary: The application of nonthermal plasma in agriculture has emerged as a sustainable and eco-friendly method to enhance seed vigor, germination, and crop productivity. This study investigates the effects of atmospheric pressure plasma treatment on five popular bread wheat varieties of North India, WH 1142, HI 1544, GW 366, GW 322, and GW 273. Direct dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) plasma exposure and plasma activated water irrigation were tested. Results indicated significant improvements in seed wettability, germination index, root and shoot growth, spike length, and grain yield compared to controls. Among treatments, 3 min DBD exposure and 15 min PAW irrigation consistently produced the best results, with variety specific differences in vigor and yield. These findings demonstrate the potential of plasma seed treatment as a chemical free technology to enhance productivity in wheat, contributing to sustainable agriculture in India.

AI.tldr: Nonthermal plasma treatment improves wheat seed vigor, germination, and yield in North Indian varieties through direct DBD exposure and plasma-activated water irrigation.
AI.motivation: To explore sustainable, chemical-free agricultural methods for enhancing wheat productivity in India using nonthermal plasma technology as an eco-friendly alternative to conventional treatments.
AI.method: Applied atmospheric pressure plasma treatment to five North Indian bread wheat varieties using two approaches: direct dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) plasma exposure and plasma-activated water (PAW) irrigation. Tested different treatment durations and compared results against control groups.
AI.result: Significant improvements in seed wettability, germination index, root and shoot growth, spike length, and grain yield. 3-minute DBD exposure and 15-minute PAW irrigation produced the best results, with variety-specific differences in vigor and yield enhancement.
AI.conclusion: Plasma seed treatment shows strong potential as a sustainable, chemical-free technology to enhance wheat productivity in India, offering an eco-friendly alternative for sustainable agriculture with variety-specific optimization needed.

title: Super Time Stepping Methods for Diffusion using Discontinuous-Galerkin Spatial Discretizations
summary: Super-time-stepping (STS) methods provide an attractive approach for enabling explicit time integration of parabolic operators, particularly in large-scale, higher-dimensional kinetic simulations where fully implicit schemes are impractical. In this work, we present an explicit STS framework tailored for diffusion operators in gyrokinetic models, motivated by the fact that constructing and storing a Jacobian is often infeasible due to strong nonlocal couplings, high dimensionality, and memory constraints. We investigate the performance of several STS methods, including Runge-Kutta-Chebyshev (RKC) and Runge-Kutta-Legendre (RKL) schemes, applied to a diffusion equation discretized using both discontinuous Galerkin (DG) and finite-difference methods. To support time adaptivity, we introduce a novel error norm designed to more accurately track temporal error arising from DG spatial discretizations, in which degrees of freedom contribute unevenly to the solution error. Finally, we assess the performance of an automatic eigenvalue estimation algorithm for determining the required number of STS stages and compare it against an analytical estimation formula.

AI.tldr: STS methods enable explicit time integration for parabolic operators in gyrokinetic simulations where implicit schemes are impractical due to memory constraints and nonlocal couplings.
AI.motivation: Constructing and storing Jacobians for implicit schemes in gyrokinetic models is infeasible due to strong nonlocal couplings, high dimensionality, and memory constraints, motivating the need for explicit STS methods.
AI.method: Develop explicit STS framework for diffusion operators in gyrokinetic models, investigate RKC and RKL schemes on diffusion equations discretized with DG and finite-difference methods, introduce novel error norm for DG time adaptivity, and assess automatic eigenvalue estimation for STS stage determination.
AI.result: The paper presents performance analysis of STS methods, introduces a specialized error norm for DG discretizations, and compares automatic eigenvalue estimation against analytical formulas for determining STS stages.
AI.conclusion: STS methods provide practical explicit time integration for gyrokinetic simulations with complex diffusion operators, with the proposed error norm and eigenvalue estimation techniques enhancing their applicability to adaptive DG discretizations.

title: FEcMD: A multi-physics and multi-scale computational program for dynamic coupling molecular dynamics simulations with transient electric field and heat conduction in metal nanostructures
comment: 57 pages, 18 figures, submitted to Computer Physics Communications
summary: Field emission coupled with molecular dynamics simulation (FEcMD) software package is a computational tool for studying atomic structure evolution, structural deformation, phase transitions, recrystallization as well as electron emission characteristics of micro- and nano-protrusions and nanowires consisting of elemental metals or multi-component alloys by means of multi-physics and multi-scale methodology. Current implementations of molecular dynamics simulation coupled with multi-scale electrodynamics (ED) and heat conduction (HC) in FEcMD program are advanced mainly in the two aspects as follows. In electrodynamics, the FEcMD program incorporates the space charge interactions (space charge potential and exchange-correlation effects) in the self-consistent solved Poisson-Schrödinger equation with Wentzel-Kramers-Brillouin-Jeffreys (WKBJ) approximation to evaluate the field emission current density and the related resistive heating process more reliably for nanowires or nano-protrusions especially for nano-gaps between two metal electrodes. Meanwhile, the two-temperature heat conduction model is implemented in electrodynamics coupled with molecular dynamics simulations (ED-MD), providing more dedicated descriptions for the hierarchical electron-phonon two-channel heat conduction mechanism and the temperature evolutions of electron and phonon subsystems under the radiofrequency (RF) or pulse electric fields. Benchmark tests are performed for some key implementations in FEcMD software to validate the numerical results, and also to demonstrate the use of program to study the atomic structure evolution of metal nano-structures under electric field and heating processes.

AI.tldr: FEcMD is a multi-physics software package combining molecular dynamics with electrodynamics and heat conduction to study field emission, structural evolution, and thermal effects in metal nanostructures under electric fields.
AI.motivation: To develop a comprehensive computational tool for studying atomic structure evolution, phase transitions, and electron emission characteristics in metal nanostructures under electric fields, addressing limitations in existing methods for handling space charge effects and electron-phonon heat conduction.
AI.method: Combines molecular dynamics simulation with multi-scale electrodynamics and heat conduction models. Uses self-consistent Poisson-Schrödinger equation with WKBJ approximation for field emission current density, incorporates space charge interactions, and implements two-temperature heat conduction model for electron-phonon thermal dynamics.
AI.result: Developed FEcMD software package with validated implementations through benchmark tests, enabling reliable study of field emission current density, resistive heating, and atomic structure evolution in metal nanowires and nano-protrusions under RF/pulse electric fields.
AI.conclusion: FEcMD provides an advanced multi-physics platform for studying complex phenomena in metal nanostructures under electric fields, offering improved reliability for field emission and thermal analysis through integrated electrodynamics, heat conduction, and molecular dynamics simulations.

title: The stochastic nonlocal Cahn-Hilliard equation with regular potential and multiplicative noise
summary: In this work, we deal with the stochastic counterpart of the nonlocal Cahn-Hilliard equation with regular potential in a smooth bounded two- or three-dimensional domain. The problem is endowed with homogeneous Neumann boundary conditions and random initial data. Furthermore, the system is driven by cylindrical noise of multiplicative type. For the resulting system, we are able to show the existence of probabilistically-weak (or martingale) solutions in two and three dimensions, that are unique and probabilistically-strong under suitable assumptions on the stochastic diffusion. Moreover, we investigate the nonlocal-to-local asymptotics toward solutions of the local stochastic Cahn-Hilliard equations, establishing, under regularity conditions, a precise rate of convergence as well.

AI.tldr: Existence and uniqueness of probabilistically-weak/strong solutions for stochastic nonlocal Cahn-Hilliard equation with multiplicative noise, plus convergence rates to local stochastic version.
AI.motivation: Study stochastic counterpart of nonlocal Cahn-Hilliard equation with regular potential in bounded domains, driven by multiplicative cylindrical noise, to establish solution existence and investigate nonlocal-to-local asymptotics.
AI.method: Analyze stochastic PDE system with homogeneous Neumann boundary conditions and random initial data, using probabilistic methods to show existence of martingale solutions, uniqueness under certain conditions, and convergence analysis for nonlocal-to-local limit.
AI.result: Proved existence of probabilistically-weak solutions in 2D/3D, uniqueness and probabilistically-strong solutions under suitable stochastic diffusion assumptions, and established precise convergence rates for nonlocal-to-local asymptotics under regularity conditions.
AI.conclusion: The stochastic nonlocal Cahn-Hilliard equation admits well-defined probabilistic solutions, and converges to its local counterpart with quantifiable rates, extending the deterministic theory to stochastic setting with multiplicative noise.

title: GPU Acceleration and Portability of the TRIMEG Code for Gyrokinetic Plasma Simulations using OpenMP
comment: 106 pages, 20 figures, Master's thesis in High Performance Computing Engineering. Carried out under the supervision of Zhixin Lu and Gianluca Palermo
summary: The field of plasma physics heavily relies on simulations to model various phenomena, such as instabilities, turbulence, and nonlinear behaviors that would otherwise be difficult to study from a purely theoretical approach. Simulations are fundamental in accurately setting up experiments, which can be extremely costly and complex. As high-fidelity tools, gyrokinetic simulations play a crucial role in discovering new physics, interpreting experimental results, and improving the design of next-generation devices. However, their high computational costs necessitate the use of acceleration platforms to reduce execution time. This work revolves around the TRIangular MEsh based Gyrokinetic (TRIMEG) code, which performs high-accuracy particle-in-cell plasma simulations in tokamak geometries, leveraging a novel finite element approach. The rise of graphical processing units (GPUs) constitutes an occasion to satisfy such computational needs, by offloading the most expensive portion of the code to the accelerators. The chosen approach features GPU offloading with the OpenMP API, which grants portability of the code to different architectures, namely AMD and NVIDIA. The particle pushing as well as the grid-to-particle operations have been ported to GPU platforms. Compiler limitations had to be overcome, and portions of the code were restructured to be suitable for GPU acceleration. Kernel performance was evaluated by carrying out GPU grid size exploration, as well as scalability studies. In addition, the efficiency of hybrid MPI-OpenMP offloading parallelization was assessed. The speedup of the GPU implementation was calculated by comparing it with the pure CPU version using different rationales. The Ion Temperature Gradient (ITG) mode was simulated using the GPU-accelerated version, and its correctness was verified in terms of the energy growth rate and the two-dimensional mode structures.

AI.tldr: GPU acceleration of TRIMEG gyrokinetic plasma simulation code using OpenMP offloading for particle pushing and grid-to-particle operations, achieving speedup while maintaining accuracy for ITG mode simulations.
AI.motivation: Gyrokinetic simulations are computationally expensive but essential for plasma physics research, requiring acceleration platforms like GPUs to reduce execution time while maintaining high accuracy for tokamak geometry simulations.
AI.method: Used OpenMP API for GPU offloading to achieve portability across AMD and NVIDIA architectures. Ported particle pushing and grid-to-particle operations to GPUs, restructured code for GPU acceleration, overcame compiler limitations, and performed performance optimization through grid size exploration and scalability studies.
AI.result: Successfully implemented GPU acceleration with measured speedup compared to CPU-only version. Verified correctness by simulating Ion Temperature Gradient (ITG) mode and confirming energy growth rates and 2D mode structures match expected results.
AI.conclusion: GPU offloading with OpenMP provides an effective approach to accelerate TRIMEG gyrokinetic simulations while maintaining code portability and physical accuracy, enabling more efficient plasma physics research.

title: A Cordes framework for stationary Fokker--Planck--Kolmogorov equations
summary: We first review the Cordes condition for nondivergence-form differential operators through the lens of Campanato's theory of near operators. We then survey a recently proposed Cordes framework that guarantees the existence and uniqueness of $L^2$ solutions to stationary Fokker--Planck--Kolmogorov equations subject to periodic boundary conditions, and that allows for the construction of a simple finite element method for its numerical approximation. Finally, we propose a Cordes framework for stationary Fokker--Planck--Kolmogorov-type equations subject to a homogeneous Dirichlet boundary condition.

AI.tldr: The paper reviews Cordes conditions for nondivergence-form operators using Campanato's theory, surveys existing Cordes frameworks for periodic boundary Fokker-Planck-Kolmogorov equations, and proposes a new Cordes framework for Dirichlet boundary conditions.
AI.motivation: To develop theoretical frameworks for analyzing and solving stationary Fokker-Planck-Kolmogorov equations with different boundary conditions, building on Cordes conditions and Campanato's theory of near operators.
AI.method: 1) Review Cordes conditions through Campanato's near operator theory; 2) Survey existing Cordes framework for periodic boundary conditions with L² solutions and finite element methods; 3) Propose new Cordes framework for homogeneous Dirichlet boundary conditions.
AI.result: The paper presents a comprehensive theoretical framework that connects Cordes conditions with Campanato's theory, surveys existing results for periodic boundary problems, and introduces a new framework for Dirichlet boundary conditions.
AI.conclusion: Cordes conditions provide a powerful framework for analyzing stationary Fokker-Planck-Kolmogorov equations with different boundary conditions, enabling both theoretical existence/uniqueness results and practical numerical approximation methods.

title: p-Wasserstein distances on networks and 3D to 1D convergence
summary:
We study transport distances on metric graphs representing gas networks. Starting from the dynamic formulation of the Wasserstein distance, we review extensions to networks, with and without the possibility of storing mass on the vertices.
  Next, we examine the asymptotic behavior of the static Wasserstein distance on a three-dimensional network domain that converges to a metric graph. We show convergence of the distance with a proof that is based on the characterization of optimal transport plans as $c$-cyclically monotone sets.
  We conclude by illustrating our finding with several numerical examples.

AI.tldr: Analysis of Wasserstein transport distances on metric graphs for gas networks, including dynamic formulations, vertex mass storage, asymptotic convergence to graph limits, and numerical validation.
AI.motivation: To understand transport distances on metric graphs representing gas networks, which requires extending Wasserstein distances to network structures and studying their convergence properties as network domains approach graph limits.
AI.method: 1) Review dynamic Wasserstein formulations extended to networks with/without vertex mass storage; 2) Analyze asymptotic behavior of static Wasserstein distance on 3D network domains converging to metric graphs using c-cyclically monotone optimal transport plan characterization.
AI.result: Demonstrated convergence of Wasserstein distance as 3D network domains approach metric graph limits, with proof based on c-cyclically monotone optimal transport plan characterization, validated through numerical examples.
AI.conclusion: Theoretical framework established for Wasserstein transport distances on metric graphs with convergence guarantees, providing mathematical foundation for gas network analysis with practical numerical validation.

title: Finite-dimensional approximations of random attractor for stochastic discrete complex Ginzburg-Landau equations
summary: In this paper, we apply an implicit Euler scheme to discretize the complex Ginzburg-Landau equation and prove the existence of a numerical attractor for the discrete Ginzburg-Landau system. We establish the upper semicontinuity of the numerical attractor with respect to the global attractor as the time step tends to zero. Furthermore, we provide finite-dimensional approximations for three types of attractors (global, numerical, and random), and demonstrate the existence of truncated attractors along with their convergence as the dimension of the state space tends to infinity. Finally, we prove the existence of a random attractor and establish the upper semi-continuity both of the global random attractor and the truncated random attractor.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes numerical discretization of the complex Ginzburg-Landau equation using implicit Euler scheme, proving existence of numerical attractors and their convergence properties.
AI.motivation: To develop numerical methods for the complex Ginzburg-Landau equation that preserve important dynamical properties like attractors, and to establish rigorous convergence results between discrete and continuous systems.
AI.method: Apply implicit Euler scheme for time discretization of the complex Ginzburg-Landau equation. Use dynamical systems theory to analyze attractors, including global attractors, numerical attractors, and random attractors. Employ finite-dimensional approximations and truncation techniques.
AI.result: Proved existence of numerical attractor for the discrete system. Established upper semicontinuity of numerical attractor with respect to global attractor as time step → 0. Provided finite-dimensional approximations for three attractor types. Demonstrated existence of truncated attractors with convergence as state space dimension → ∞. Proved existence of random attractor with upper semicontinuity properties.
AI.conclusion: The implicit Euler scheme successfully preserves attractor structures for the complex Ginzburg-Landau equation, with rigorous convergence guarantees between discrete and continuous systems, and between finite-dimensional approximations and infinite-dimensional systems.

title: Sharp macroscopic blow-up behavior for the parabolic-elliptic Keller-Segel system in dimensions $n\ge 3$
summary: We study the space-time concentration or blow-up asymptotics of radially decreasing solutions of the parabolic-elliptic Keller-Segel system in the whole space or in a ball. We show that, for any solution in dimensions $3\le n\le 9$ (assuming finite mass in the whole space case), there exists a nonflat backward self-similar solution $U$ such that $$u(x,t)=(1+o(1))U(x,t),\quad\hbox{as $(x,t)\to (0,T)$.}$$ This macroscopic behavior is important from the physical point of view, since it gives a sharp description of the concentration phenomenon in the scale of the original space-time variables~$(x,t)$. It strongly improves on existing results, since such behavior was previously known (\cite{GMS}) to hold only in the microscopic scale $|x|\le O(\sqrt{T-t})$ as $t\to T$ (and in the whole space case only). As a consequence, we obtain the two-sided global estimate $$C_1\le (T-t+|x|^2)u(x,t)\le C_2\quad\hbox{in $B_R\times(T/2,T)$},$$ whose upper part only was known before (\cite{Soup-Win}), as well as the sharp final profile: $$\lim_{x\to 0} |x|^2u(x,T)=L\in(0,\infty).$$ The latter improves, with a different proof, the recent result of \cite{BZ} by excluding the possibility $L=0$. We also give extensions of these results, in higher dimensions, to type~I and to time monotone solutions. Moreover, we extend the known results on type I estimates and on convergence in similarity variables, and significantly simplify their proofs.

AI.tldr: The paper establishes precise space-time blow-up asymptotics for radially decreasing solutions of the parabolic-elliptic Keller-Segel system in dimensions 3-9, showing convergence to nonflat backward self-similar solutions and obtaining sharp global estimates.
AI.motivation: To provide a sharp macroscopic description of concentration phenomena in the Keller-Segel system, improving previous results that were limited to microscopic scales and lacked complete two-sided estimates.
AI.method: Analysis of radially decreasing solutions in dimensions 3-9, establishing convergence to nonflat backward self-similar solutions as blow-up occurs, with extensions to type I and time monotone solutions in higher dimensions.
AI.result: Proves existence of nonflat backward self-similar solutions such that u(x,t) ~ U(x,t) as (x,t) → (0,T), obtains two-sided global estimates C₁ ≤ (T-t+|x|²)u(x,t) ≤ C₂, and shows sharp final profile lim_{x→0} |x|²u(x,T) = L ∈ (0,∞).
AI.conclusion: The work provides complete macroscopic blow-up asymptotics for Keller-Segel system, significantly improving previous results by establishing two-sided estimates, excluding degenerate limits, and simplifying proofs while extending to broader solution classes.

title: Understanding Carbon Sourcing and Transport Originating from the Helicon Antenna Surfaces During High-Power Helicon Discharge in DIII-D Tokamak
summary: The high-power helicon wave system in the DIII-D tokamak introduces new plasma--material interaction (PMI) challenges due to rectified RF sheath potentials forming near antenna structures and surrounding tiles. Using the STRIPE modeling framework-which integrates SOLPS-ITER, COMSOL, RustBCA, and GITR/GITRm-we simulate carbon erosion, re-deposition, and global impurity transport in two H-mode discharges with varying antenna--plasma gaps and RF powers. COMSOL predicts rectified sheath potentials of 1-5 kV, localized near the bottom of the antenna where magnetic field lines intersect at grazing angles. Erosion is dominated by carbon self-sputtering, with RF-accelerated D+ ions contributing up to 1 % of the total erosion flux. GITRm simulations show that in the small-gap case, only ~ 13 % of eroded carbon is re-deposited locally, with 58 % transported into the core. In contrast, the large-gap case exhibits lower total erosion, along with reduced core penetration (~ 35 %) and weaker re-deposition (~ 4 %), consistent with lower collisionality and limited plasma contact. The simulation trends are consistent with experimental observations, which have not shown elevated core impurity levels during helicon operation in the present graphite-wall configuration. However, under certain plasma conditions and magnetic configurations, the helicon antenna may still act as a finite source of net erosion and core-directed impurity transport, potentially influencing the overall core impurity balance. These findings emphasize the need for sheath-aware antenna designs and predictive impurity transport modeling to support future high-power RF systems with high-Z first wall materials in fusion devices.

AI.tldr: Simulation study of RF sheath-induced carbon erosion and impurity transport from DIII-D helicon antenna shows varying erosion/re-deposition patterns based on antenna-plasma gap and RF power, with implications for future high-power RF systems.
AI.motivation: High-power helicon wave systems in tokamaks create plasma-material interaction challenges due to RF sheath potentials near antenna structures, which can cause erosion and impurity transport affecting plasma performance.
AI.method: Used STRIPE modeling framework integrating SOLPS-ITER, COMSOL, RustBCA, and GITR/GITRm to simulate carbon erosion, re-deposition, and global impurity transport in two H-mode discharges with varying antenna-plasma gaps and RF powers.
AI.result: Small-gap case: 13% local re-deposition, 58% core transport. Large-gap case: lower erosion, 4% re-deposition, 35% core penetration. RF-accelerated D+ ions contribute up to 1% of erosion. COMSOL predicts 1-5 kV sheath potentials near antenna bottom.
AI.conclusion: Helicon antenna can act as finite erosion source and impurity transport pathway under certain conditions. Findings emphasize need for sheath-aware antenna designs and predictive impurity transport modeling for future high-power RF systems with high-Z materials.

title: RANDSMAPs: Random-Feature/multi-Scale Neural Decoders with Mass Preservation
comment: 47 pages (23 in main text, 24 in Appendix), 19 figures (4 in main text, 15 in Appendix), 10 Tables (in Appendix)
summary: We introduce RANDSMAPs (Random-feature/multi-scale neural decoders with Mass Preservation), numerical analysis-informed, explainable neural decoders designed to explicitly respect conservation laws when solving the challenging ill-posed pre-image problem in manifold learning. We start by proving the equivalence of vanilla random Fourier feature neural networks to Radial Basis Function interpolation and the double Diffusion Maps (based on Geometric Harmonics) decoders in the deterministic limit. We then establish the theoretical foundations for RANDSMAP and introduce its multiscale variant to capture structures across multiple scales. We formulate and derive the closed-form solution of the corresponding constrained optimization problem and prove the mass preservation property. Numerically, we assess the performance of RANDSMAP on three benchmark problems/datasets with mass preservation obtained by the Lighthill-Whitham-Richards traffic flow PDE with shock waves, 2D rotated MRI brain images, and the Hughes crowd dynamics PDEs. We demonstrate that RANDSMAPs yield high reconstruction accuracy at low computational cost and maintain mass conservation at single-machine precision. In its vanilla formulation, the scheme remains applicable to the classical pre-image problem, i.e., when mass-preservation constraints are not imposed.

AI.tldr: RANDSMAPs are neural decoders that preserve mass when solving ill-posed pre-image problems in manifold learning, combining random Fourier features with conservation law constraints.
AI.motivation: The paper addresses the challenging ill-posed pre-image problem in manifold learning where standard methods don't respect physical conservation laws like mass preservation, which is crucial for applications in traffic flow, medical imaging, and crowd dynamics.
AI.method: Develops RANDSMAPs (Random-feature/multi-scale neural decoders with Mass Preservation) that combine random Fourier feature neural networks with explicit mass preservation constraints. The method includes: 1) proving equivalence between random Fourier networks and existing methods, 2) establishing theoretical foundations, 3) introducing multiscale variants, 4) formulating constrained optimization with closed-form solutions, and 5) proving mass preservation properties.
AI.result: The method achieves high reconstruction accuracy at low computational cost while maintaining mass conservation at single-machine precision. It was validated on three benchmark problems: Lighthill-Whitham-Richards traffic flow PDE with shock waves, 2D rotated MRI brain images, and Hughes crowd dynamics PDEs.
AI.conclusion: RANDSMAPs provide an explainable, numerically-informed neural decoder framework that explicitly respects conservation laws while solving ill-posed pre-image problems, with applications extending beyond mass preservation to classical pre-image problems.

title: LiDRoSIS: An Automated MATLAB-Python Platform for Image Processing and Quantitative Analysis of Lipid Droplets and ROS in Irradiated Cells
comment: 7 pages, 3 figures. Software and data available at https://github.com/marco18010104/LiDRoSIS and https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.17407192. For a more detailed article, please reachout fc60327@alunos.fc.ul.pt
summary: LiDRoSIS is an automated MATLAB-Python software suite for the segmentation and quantification of lipid droplets (LDs) and reactive oxygen species (ROS) in fluorescence microscopy images of irradiated A549 and MCF7 cells exposed to gold-based nanoparticles. It combines classical image processing algorithms with statistical post-analysis through a companion Python tool, StatLysis. The platform enables reproducible, high-throughput analysis of morphological and spectral parameters linked to nanoparticle-enhanced radiobiological responses. By bridging imaging and quantitative analytics, LiDRoSIS provides a robust framework for nanomedicine and radiation biology research.

AI.tldr: LiDRoSIS is an automated MATLAB-Python software for segmenting and quantifying lipid droplets and reactive oxygen species in fluorescence microscopy images of irradiated cells with gold nanoparticles.
AI.motivation: To provide a reproducible, high-throughput analysis platform for studying nanoparticle-enhanced radiobiological responses by bridging imaging and quantitative analytics in nanomedicine and radiation biology research.
AI.method: Combines classical image processing algorithms in MATLAB with statistical post-analysis through a companion Python tool called StatLysis for segmentation and quantification of lipid droplets and reactive oxygen species.
AI.result: Enables automated analysis of morphological and spectral parameters in fluorescence microscopy images of irradiated A549 and MCF7 cells exposed to gold-based nanoparticles.
AI.conclusion: LiDRoSIS provides a robust framework for nanomedicine and radiation biology research by offering reproducible, high-throughput analysis of nanoparticle-enhanced radiobiological responses.

title: Global solution curves in harmonic parameters, and multiplicity of solutions
summary: \[ Δu+g(u)=f(x) \s \mbox{for $x \in Ω$}, \s u=0 \s \mbox{on $\partial Ω$} \] decompose $f(x)=μ_1 \p _1+e(x)$, where $\p _1$ is the principal eigenfunction of the Laplacian with zero boundary conditions, and $e(x) \perp \p _1$ in $L^2(Ω)$, and similarly write $u(x)= ξ_1 \p _i+U (x)$, with $ U \perp \p _1$ in $L^2(Ω)$. We study properties of the solution curve $(u(x),μ_1)(ξ_1)$, and in particular its section $μ_1=μ_1(ξ_1)$, which governs the multiplicity of solutions. We consider both general nonlinearities, and some important classes of equations, and obtain detailed description of solution curves under the assumption $g'(u)<\la _2$. We obtain particularly detailed results in case of one dimension. This approach is well suited for numerical computations, which we perform to illustrate our results.

AI.tldr: The paper studies solution curves for semilinear elliptic PDEs with nonlinear term g(u) and forcing term f(x), focusing on multiplicity of solutions through decomposition into principal eigenfunction components.
AI.motivation: To understand the structure and multiplicity of solutions for semilinear elliptic boundary value problems by analyzing solution curves in terms of projections onto the principal eigenfunction.
AI.method: Decompose both solution u(x) and forcing term f(x) into principal eigenfunction components (ξ₁φ₁ + U and μ₁φ₁ + e), then study properties of the solution curve (u(x), μ₁)(ξ₁), particularly the section μ₁ = μ₁(ξ₁) that governs solution multiplicity.
AI.result: Obtain detailed description of solution curves under the assumption g'(u) < λ₂ (second eigenvalue), with particularly detailed results for one-dimensional problems. The approach is validated through numerical computations.
AI.conclusion: The decomposition method provides an effective framework for analyzing solution multiplicity in semilinear elliptic PDEs, especially suitable for numerical implementation and yielding comprehensive results in one-dimensional cases.

title: Triggers for plasma detachment bifurcation in the edge divertor region of tokamaks
summary: We report the discovery of the trigger for detachment bifurcation phenomenon in tokamak divertors, revealed through steady-state and time-dependent UEDGE simulations: The observed electron temperature cliff at the outer target in DIII-D H-mode plasmas with ion $B\times \nabla B$ drift driven into the active divertor results from a bifurcation-induced $T_e$ drop above the X-point accompanied by reversal of the $E\times B$ flow pattern in the private flux region. Time-dependent simulations reveal a two-phase transition mechanism: the high-field-side radiation front first extends across the last closed flux surface and stabilizes above the X-point, causing local $T_e$ to drop from $\sim 70\,\mathrm{eV}$ to $\sim 10\,\mathrm{eV}$ and inducing $E\times B$ flow reversal in a thin layer below the X-point, which lasts $< 0.5\,\mathrm{ms}$; Flow reversal below the X-point subsequently triggers the sharp drop in outer target temperature on a timescale of $1-2\,\mathrm{ms}$, establishing deep detachment a few ms thereafter. A bifurcation transition occurs when the high-field-side radiation front crosses the separatrix while the outer divertor remains attached, with the $T_e$ cliff manifesting distinctly when the outer target $T_e \gtrsim 10\,\mathrm{eV}$ prior to the bifurcation. These results demonstrate that the bifurcation is linked to in-out divertor asymmetry and asymmetric radiation front evolution.

AI.tldr: Discovery of trigger mechanism for detachment bifurcation in tokamak divertors: radiation front crossing separatrix causes temperature cliff and flow reversal.
AI.motivation: To understand the trigger mechanism behind detachment bifurcation phenomena observed in tokamak divertors, particularly the electron temperature cliff at outer targets in DIII-D H-mode plasmas.
AI.method: Used steady-state and time-dependent UEDGE simulations to analyze DIII-D H-mode plasmas with ion B×∇B drift into active divertor, examining radiation front evolution and E×B flow patterns.
AI.result: Identified two-phase transition: 1) HFS radiation front crosses separatrix, stabilizes above X-point causing Te drop from ~70eV to ~10eV and E×B flow reversal (<0.5ms), 2) Flow reversal triggers outer target temperature cliff (1-2ms), leading to deep detachment. Bifurcation occurs when radiation front crosses separatrix while outer divertor remains attached.
AI.conclusion: Detachment bifurcation is triggered by high-field-side radiation front crossing the separatrix, causing temperature drop and flow reversal, with the phenomenon linked to in-out divertor asymmetry and asymmetric radiation front evolution.

title: Modal-Centric Field Inversion via Differentiable Proper Orthogonal Decomposition
summary: Inverse problems in computational physics often require matching high-dimensional spatio-temporal fields, leading to prohibitive computational costs and ill-conditioned optimizations. We introduce modal-centric field inversion (MCFI), a paradigm that reformulates inverse problems in the reduced space of proper orthogonal decomposition (POD) modes rather than the full physical state space. By targeting dominant flow structures instead of point-wise field values, MCFI provides a compact, physically meaningful objective that naturally regularizes the inversion and dramatically reduces computational burden. Central to this framework is the differentiable POD: an adjoint-based method that efficiently computes sensitivities of POD modes with respect to model parameters, enabling gradient-based optimization in the modal space. We demonstrate MCFI on a one and two-dimensional modified viscous Burger's equation, optimizing spatially varying coefficients to match target dynamics through mode-matching. The adjoint formulation achieves computational cost independent of parameter dimension, in contrast to finite-difference approaches that scale linearly. MCFI establishes a foundation for scalable inverse design and model calibration in unsteady, high-dimensional systems.

AI.tldr: MCFI reformulates inverse problems in POD modal space instead of physical state space, reducing computational cost and improving conditioning through mode-matching objectives.
AI.motivation: Inverse problems in computational physics face prohibitive computational costs and ill-conditioned optimizations when matching high-dimensional spatio-temporal fields directly in physical space.
AI.method: Modal-centric field inversion (MCFI) operates in reduced POD modal space with differentiable POD for adjoint-based sensitivity computation, enabling gradient-based optimization through mode-matching objectives.
AI.result: Demonstrated on 1D/2D modified viscous Burger's equation, MCFI achieves computational cost independent of parameter dimension (vs linear scaling for finite-difference) and provides natural regularization.
AI.conclusion: MCFI establishes a scalable foundation for inverse design and model calibration in unsteady, high-dimensional systems by targeting dominant flow structures rather than point-wise field values.

title: QDK/Chemistry: A Modular Toolkit for Quantum Chemistry Applications
summary: We present QDK/Chemistry, a software toolkit for quantum chemistry workflows targeting quantum computers. The toolkit addresses a key challenge in the field: while quantum algorithms for chemistry have matured considerably, the infrastructure connecting classical electronic structure calculations to quantum circuit execution remains fragmented. QDK/Chemistry provides this infrastructure through a modular architecture that separates data representations from computational methods, enabling researchers to compose workflows from interchangeable components. In addition to providing native implementations of targeted algorithms in the quantum-classical pipeline, the toolkit builds upon and integrates with widely used open-source quantum chemistry packages and quantum computing frameworks through a plugin system, allowing users to combine methods from different sources without modifying workflow logic. This paper describes the design philosophy, current capabilities, and role of QDK/Chemistry as a foundation for reproducible quantum chemistry experiments.

AI.tldr: QDK/Chemistry is a modular software toolkit that bridges classical quantum chemistry calculations with quantum circuit execution, providing infrastructure for reproducible quantum chemistry experiments.
AI.motivation: The field lacks integrated infrastructure connecting classical electronic structure calculations to quantum circuit execution, despite mature quantum algorithms for chemistry. Existing solutions are fragmented, making it difficult to compose and reproduce quantum chemistry workflows.
AI.method: The toolkit uses a modular architecture that separates data representations from computational methods, enabling interchangeable components. It includes native algorithm implementations and integrates with existing quantum chemistry packages and quantum computing frameworks through a plugin system.
AI.result: QDK/Chemistry provides a unified infrastructure for quantum chemistry workflows that allows researchers to combine methods from different sources without modifying workflow logic, addressing the fragmentation in the field.
AI.conclusion: The toolkit serves as a foundation for reproducible quantum chemistry experiments by providing the missing infrastructure layer between classical calculations and quantum execution, with extensibility through its plugin architecture.

title: Uniqueness of Ground State Solutions for a Defocusing Hartree Equation via Inverse Optimal Problems
summary: We study a generalized defocusing Hartree equation with nonlocal exchange potential and repulsive Hartree--Fock interaction. Using an inverse optimal problem (IOP) approach, we prove the existence and uniqueness of ground state solutions. Additionally, we establish the existence of principal solutions, their continuous dependence on parameters, and a dual variational formulation. The IOP method provides a systematic framework for addressing inverse problems in nonlocal Schrödinger operators and offers new insights into the structure of solutions for defocusing Hartree-type equations.

AI.tldr: Existence and uniqueness of ground state solutions for defocusing Hartree equation with nonlocal exchange potential using inverse optimal problem approach.
AI.motivation: To study defocusing Hartree equations with nonlocal exchange potential and repulsive Hartree-Fock interaction, addressing inverse problems in nonlocal Schrödinger operators.
AI.method: Inverse optimal problem (IOP) approach to prove existence and uniqueness of ground state solutions, plus analysis of principal solutions and dual variational formulation.
AI.result: Proved existence and uniqueness of ground state solutions, established existence of principal solutions with continuous parameter dependence, and developed dual variational formulation.
AI.conclusion: IOP method provides systematic framework for inverse problems in nonlocal Schrödinger operators and offers new insights into solution structure for defocusing Hartree-type equations.

title: Electric field induced by radial redistribution of the energetic ion pressure in a fusion plasma
summary: It is found by using the gyrokinetic theory that significant radial electric fields, or zonal flows, can be generated by the radial redistribution of energetic ion pressure in a tokamak fusion device. Trapped energetic ions are more effective to generate the radial electric field than the isotropic energetic ions. This suggests that the energetic $α$ particles produced by DT fusion may induce significant radial electric field and thus help to improve the core plasma confinement in a fusion reactor.

AI.tldr: Energetic ions, especially trapped ones, can generate significant radial electric fields (zonal flows) in tokamaks through pressure redistribution, potentially improving plasma confinement in fusion reactors.
AI.motivation: To understand how energetic particles (particularly α particles from DT fusion) can influence plasma confinement in tokamak fusion devices by generating radial electric fields.
AI.method: Using gyrokinetic theory to analyze the generation of radial electric fields through radial redistribution of energetic ion pressure, comparing trapped vs. isotropic energetic ions.
AI.result: Trapped energetic ions are more effective at generating radial electric fields than isotropic energetic ions. Energetic α particles from DT fusion may induce significant radial electric fields.
AI.conclusion: The radial electric fields generated by energetic ions, particularly trapped α particles, could help improve core plasma confinement in fusion reactors.

title: Generalized preconditioned conjugate gradients for adaptive FEM with optimal complexity
summary: We consider adaptive finite element methods (AFEMs) with inexact algebraic solver for second-order symmetric linear elliptic diffusion problems. We formulate and analyze a non-linear and non-symmetric geometric multigrid preconditioner for the generalized preconditioned conjugate gradient method (GPCG) used to solve the arising finite element systems. Moreover, a linear and symmetric variant of the geometric multigrid preconditioner that is suitable for the (standard) preconditioned conjugate gradient method (PCG) is provided and analyzed. We show that both preconditioners are optimal in the sense that, first, the resulting algebraic solvers admit a contraction factor that is independent of the local mesh size h and the polynomial degree p, and, second, that they can be applied with linear computational complexity. Related to this, quasi-optimal computational cost of the overall adaptive finite element method is addressed. Numerical experiments underline the theoretical findings.

AI.tldr: AFEM with inexact algebraic solver for elliptic problems using optimal geometric multigrid preconditioners for GPCG/PCG with h- and p-independent contraction and linear complexity.
AI.motivation: To develop efficient adaptive finite element methods for elliptic diffusion problems that combine inexact algebraic solvers with optimal preconditioners to achieve computational efficiency while maintaining accuracy.
AI.method: Formulate and analyze non-linear/non-symmetric geometric multigrid preconditioner for GPCG, plus linear/symmetric variant for PCG. Both preconditioners are designed to be optimal with mesh size and polynomial degree independence.
AI.result: Both preconditioners are optimal: contraction factor independent of mesh size h and polynomial degree p, applicable with linear computational complexity. Numerical experiments support theoretical findings.
AI.conclusion: The proposed geometric multigrid preconditioners enable efficient adaptive finite element methods with inexact algebraic solvers, achieving quasi-optimal computational cost for elliptic diffusion problems.

title: Nontrivial integrable weak stationary solutions to active scalar equations with non-odd drift
summary: In this paper we construct nontrivial weak solutions to a class of stationary active scalar equations with a non-odd nonlocal operator in the drift term using a convex integration scheme. We show our solutions lie in $$ \bigcap_{0 < ε< 1} \dot{B}^{-ε}_{\infty,\infty}(\mathbb{T}^d) \cap L^{2-ε}(\mathbb{T}^d) $$ for $d \geq 2$. The key ingredient of the construction is the use of highly oscillatory corrections with a variable degree of intermittency, which is arranged to decrease to zero at higher stages of the iteration procedure.

AI.tldr: Construct nontrivial weak solutions to stationary active scalar equations with non-odd nonlocal operators using convex integration, achieving solutions in specific function spaces.
AI.motivation: To develop existence results for stationary active scalar equations with non-odd nonlocal operators, which are challenging due to the lack of symmetry properties in the drift term.
AI.method: Convex integration scheme with highly oscillatory corrections featuring variable intermittency that decreases at higher iteration stages.
AI.result: Constructed nontrivial weak solutions that belong to the intersection of Besov spaces $\bigcap_{0 < ε< 1} \dot{B}^{-ε}_{\infty,\infty}(\mathbb{T}^d)$ and Lebesgue spaces $L^{2-ε}(\mathbb{T}^d)$ for dimensions $d \geq 2$.
AI.conclusion: Convex integration with carefully designed oscillatory corrections can successfully construct weak solutions for stationary active scalar equations with non-odd nonlocal operators, achieving solutions in specific low-regularity function spaces.

title: Piecewise omnigenous magnetohydrodynamic equilibria as fusion reactor candidates
summary: In piecewise omnigenous magnetic fields, charged particles remain perfectly confined in the abscence of collisions and turbulence. This concept extends the traditional notion of omnigenity, the theoretical principle upon which most of existing magnetic fusion reactor designs, including tokamaks, are based. While piecewise omnigenity broadens the range of potentially viable stellarator reactor candidates, it is achieved by relaxing the requirement of continuity in the magnetic field strength, which could appear to pose significant challenges for the design of magnetohydrodynamic equilibria. In this work, a stellarator magnetic configuration is presented that satisfies the ideal magnetohydrodynamic equilibrium equation and that achieves unprecedented levels of piecewise omnigenity. As a result, it exhibits favorable transport characteristics, including reduced bulk radial (neoclassical and turbulent transport), bootstrap current and fast ion losses. In addition, the configuration displays robust MHD stability across a range of \b{eta} values and possesses a rotational transform profile compatible with an island divertor. Collectively, these features satisfy the standard set of physics criteria required for a viable reactor candidate which, until now, were believed to be attainable only by certain types of omnigenous stellarators.

AI.tldr: A stellarator configuration achieves piecewise omnigenity while satisfying ideal MHD equilibrium, showing improved transport, stability, and reactor viability comparable to omnigenous designs.
AI.motivation: Piecewise omnigenous fields offer perfect particle confinement but require discontinuous magnetic field strength, posing challenges for MHD equilibrium design. The paper aims to demonstrate a stellarator configuration that achieves both piecewise omnigenity and ideal MHD equilibrium.
AI.method: Developed a stellarator magnetic configuration that satisfies the ideal magnetohydrodynamic equilibrium equation while achieving unprecedented levels of piecewise omnigenity.
AI.result: The configuration exhibits favorable transport characteristics (reduced neoclassical/turbulent transport, bootstrap current, fast ion losses), robust MHD stability across beta values, and rotational transform compatible with island divertor.
AI.conclusion: The configuration satisfies standard reactor physics criteria previously believed attainable only by certain omnigenous stellarators, broadening viable stellarator reactor candidates.

title: Rank-one Riemannian Subspace Descent for Nonlinear Matrix Equations
summary: We propose a rank-one Riemannian subspace descent algorithm for computing symmetric positive definite (SPD) solutions to nonlinear matrix equations arising in control theory, dynamic programming, and stochastic filtering. For solution matrices of size $n\times n$, standard approaches for dense matrix equations typically incur $\mathcal{O}(n^3)$ cost per-iteration, while the efficient $\mathcal{O}(n^2)$ methods either rely on sparsity or low-rank solutions, or have iteration counts that scale poorly. The proposed method entails updating along the dominant eigen-component of a transformed Riemannian gradient, identified using at most $\mathcal{O}(\log(n))$ power iterations. The update structure also enables exact step-size selection in many cases at minimal additional cost. For objectives defined as compositions of standard matrix operations, each iteration can be implemented using only matrix--vector products, yielding $\mathcal{O}(n^2)$ arithmetic cost. We prove an $\mathcal{O}(n)$ iteration bound under standard smoothness assumptions, with improved bounds under geodesic strong convexity. Numerical experiments on large-scale CARE, DARE, and other nonlinear matrix equations show that the proposed algorithm solves instances (up to $n=10{,}000$ in our tests) for which the compared solvers, including MATLAB's \texttt{icare}, structure-preserving doubling, and subspace-descent baselines fail to return a solution. These results demonstrate that rank-one manifold updates provide a practical approach for high-dimensional and dense SPD-constrained matrix equations. MATLAB code implementation is publicly available on GitHub : \href{https://github.com/yogeshd-iitk/nonlinear_matrix_equation_R1RSD}{\textcolor{blue}{https://github.com/yogeshd-iitk/nonlinear\_matrix \_equation\_R1RSD}}

AI.tldr: A rank-one Riemannian subspace descent algorithm for solving large-scale symmetric positive definite matrix equations with O(n²) per-iteration cost and O(n) iteration bound.
AI.motivation: Standard methods for dense matrix equations have O(n³) cost per iteration, while efficient O(n²) methods either require sparsity/low-rank solutions or have poor iteration scaling. There's a need for practical algorithms for high-dimensional dense SPD-constrained matrix equations.
AI.method: Rank-one Riemannian subspace descent that updates along the dominant eigen-component of a transformed Riemannian gradient using O(log(n)) power iterations. Enables exact step-size selection and can be implemented using only matrix-vector products for O(n²) cost per iteration.
AI.result: The algorithm solves large-scale instances (up to n=10,000) where existing solvers (MATLAB's icare, structure-preserving doubling, subspace-descent baselines) fail. Proves O(n) iteration bound under smoothness assumptions with improved bounds under geodesic strong convexity.
AI.conclusion: Rank-one manifold updates provide a practical approach for high-dimensional dense SPD-constrained matrix equations, demonstrated through successful application to CARE, DARE, and other nonlinear matrix equations.

title: Multiple standing waves of Helmholtz equation with mixed dispersion concentrating in the high frequency limit

AI.tldr: The paper studies a nonlinear Helmholtz equation with mixed dispersion and establishes existence of dual ground state solutions that concentrate at global maximizers of the weight function W as k→∞, across three parameter regimes.
AI.motivation: To analyze the nonlinear Helmholtz equation with mixed dispersion and understand solution behavior, particularly concentration phenomena around global maximizers of the weight function W, across different parameter regimes.
AI.method: After suitable rescaling, the authors use variational methods to prove existence of dual ground state solutions and multiple solutions, analyzing concentration behavior as k→∞.
AI.result: Existence of dual ground state solutions that concentrate along global maximizers of W as k→∞ in three parameter ranges: (a) α<0, β∈ℝ; (b) α>0, β<-2√α; (c) α=0, β<0. Also establishes existence of multiple solutions associated with global maximum points of W.
AI.conclusion: The nonlinear Helmholtz equation with mixed dispersion admits concentration solutions around global maximizers of the weight function, with precise characterization of concentration behavior across different parameter regimes.

title: Single-laser scheme for reaching strong field QED regime via direct laser acceleration
summary: We investigate a single-laser scheme for reaching the strong-field QED regime based on direct laser acceleration (DLA) of electrons followed by their head-on collision with the same laser pulse reflected from an overdense foil. In this configuration, electrons are first accelerated inside an underdense plasma by a relativistic laser pulse and subsequently interact with the reflected laser field, emitting high-energy photons via nonlinear Compton scattering which decay into electron-positron pairs through the nonlinear Breit-Wheeler process. Using analytical scalings supported by quasi-3D particle-in-cell simulations including QED effects, we demonstrate that a laser pulse with power as low as 2 PW is sufficient to reach the quantum regime characterized by $χ_e> 1$ . For higher powers, we observe a rapid nonlinear increase in the number of generated positrons, reaching more than 2 nC for a 10 PW laser pulse with energy of approximately 1.1 kJ. A semi-analytical model is employed to estimate the positron yield, showing good agreement with simulation results. We further study the influence of laser depletion and the positioning of the reflecting foil on the efficiency of pair production. The presented scheme provides an experimentally feasible platform for probing strong-field QED effects using currently available multi-petawatt laser systems.

AI.tldr: Single-laser scheme uses direct laser acceleration of electrons followed by head-on collision with reflected pulse to reach strong-field QED regime, enabling electron-positron pair production with 2+ PW lasers.
AI.motivation: To develop an experimentally feasible platform for probing strong-field QED effects using currently available multi-petawatt laser systems, overcoming the challenge of reaching the quantum regime (χ_e > 1) with lower laser power requirements.
AI.method: Two-stage process: 1) Direct laser acceleration (DLA) of electrons in underdense plasma by relativistic laser pulse, 2) Head-on collision with same laser pulse reflected from overdense foil, triggering nonlinear Compton scattering and subsequent nonlinear Breit-Wheeler pair production. Analyzed using analytical scalings and quasi-3D particle-in-cell simulations with QED effects.
AI.result: Laser pulse with power as low as 2 PW can reach quantum regime (χ_e > 1). For 10 PW laser (~1.1 kJ), positron yield exceeds 2 nC with rapid nonlinear increase. Semi-analytical model shows good agreement with simulations. Laser depletion and foil positioning affect pair production efficiency.
AI.conclusion: The presented single-laser scheme provides a practical platform for studying strong-field QED effects using existing multi-petawatt laser technology, enabling electron-positron pair production through efficient two-stage acceleration and collision process.

title: Nonclassical symmetries of polynomial equations and test problems with parameters for computer algebra systems
summary: Nonclassical symmetries and reductions of polynomial equations and systems of polynomial equations are considered. It is shown that specific polynomial equations having "hidden" symmetries can be reduced to classical symmetric systems of polynomial equations by introducing a new additional variable. It has been established that symmetric systems of polynomial equations of mixed type, consisting of symmetric and anti-symmetric polynomials, can be transformed into simpler systems. A method is presented for solving nonclassical symmetric systems of two polynomial equations that change places when the unknowns are permuted. We study polynomial equations containing the second iteration of a given polynomial, which are reduced to nonclassical symmetric systems of equations. New higher-degree polynomial equations containing free parameters that admit solutions in radicals are found. Three such equations of the sixth and ninth degrees are further used as test problems with parameters for analyzing the capabilities of two leading computer algebra systems. It is shown that currently, the Maple and Mathematica systems do not allow us to efficiently find analytical solutions (in radicals) of polynomial equations with free parameters, but they allow us to obtain numerical solutions of equations for fixed numerical values of the parameters. The results of this work and the proposed test problems with parameters can be used to further improve existing computer algebra systems.

AI.tldr: The paper explores nonclassical symmetries in polynomial equations, develops methods to transform them into simpler symmetric systems, finds new higher-degree equations solvable in radicals, and uses these as test problems to evaluate computer algebra systems.
AI.motivation: To develop methods for solving polynomial equations with nonclassical symmetries and to create test problems that challenge the capabilities of computer algebra systems like Maple and Mathematica in finding analytical solutions in radicals for parametric equations.
AI.method: Introduces additional variables to reveal hidden symmetries, transforms mixed symmetric/anti-symmetric systems into simpler forms, studies equations containing polynomial iterations, and develops specific higher-degree polynomial equations with parameters that admit radical solutions.
AI.result: Found new higher-degree polynomial equations (6th and 9th degree) with free parameters that admit solutions in radicals. These equations serve as test problems showing that current computer algebra systems (Maple, Mathematica) cannot efficiently find analytical radical solutions for parametric equations but can handle numerical solutions for fixed parameters.
AI.conclusion: The developed methods for handling nonclassical symmetric polynomial equations and the created test problems with parameters can be used to improve existing computer algebra systems' capabilities in finding analytical radical solutions for parametric polynomial equations.

title: Integrating the probe and singular sources methods: IV. IPS function for the Schrödinger equation
summary: The integrated theory of the probe and singular sources methods (IPS) is developed for an inverse obstacle problem governed by the stationary Schrödinger equation in a bounded domain. The unknown obstacles are penetrable, and their surface is modeled by a part of the support of the potential in the governing equation. The main results concern an analytical detection method for these obstacles from the Dirichlet-to-Neumann map. They consist of three parts: a singular sources method via the probe method using a solution with higher-order singularity for the governing equation of the background medium; the discovery of an IPS function whose two ways of decomposition give us the indicator functions for both the probe and singular sources methods; a completely integrated version of both methods, which means their indicator functions coincide. Furthermore, a result on Side B of IPS is also given, concerning the blowing-up property of a sequence calculated from the Dirichlet-to-Neumann map.

AI.tldr: Develops integrated theory combining probe and singular sources methods for detecting penetrable obstacles in inverse Schrödinger problems using Dirichlet-to-Neumann map.
AI.motivation: To develop a unified analytical framework for detecting unknown penetrable obstacles in inverse problems governed by stationary Schrödinger equations, where obstacles are modeled as part of the potential's support.
AI.method: Integrated Probe and Singular Sources (IPS) method using solutions with higher-order singularities, discovery of IPS function with dual decomposition properties, and complete integration of both detection approaches.
AI.result: Three main results: 1) singular sources method via probe method with higher-order singularity solutions, 2) discovery of IPS function providing indicator functions for both methods, 3) complete integration where indicator functions coincide. Additional result on blowing-up property of sequences from Dirichlet-to-Neumann map.
AI.conclusion: Successfully develops integrated theory for obstacle detection in inverse Schrödinger problems, unifying probe and singular sources methods with analytical foundation and practical detection capabilities.

title: Optimized Schwarz Waveform Relaxation for the Damped Wave Equation
summary: The performance of Schwarz Waveform Relaxation is critically dependent on the choice of transmission conditions. While classical absorbing conditions work well for wave propagation, they prove insufficient for damped wave equations, particularly in viscoelastic damping regimes where convergence becomes prohibitively slow. This paper addresses this limitation by introducing a more general transmission operator with two free parameters for the one-dimensional damped wave equation. Through frequency-domain analysis, we derive an explicit expression for the convergence factor governing the convergence rate. We propose and compare two optimization strategies (L-infinity and L-2 minimization) for determining optimal transmission parameters. Numerical experiments demonstrate that our optimized approach significantly accelerates convergence compared to standard absorbing conditions, especially for viscoelastic damping cases. The method provides a computationally efficient alternative to exhaustive parameter search while maintaining robust performance across different damping regimes.

AI.tldr: Optimized transmission conditions for Schwarz Waveform Relaxation accelerate convergence for damped wave equations, especially in viscoelastic damping regimes.
AI.motivation: Classical absorbing transmission conditions work well for wave propagation but prove insufficient for damped wave equations, particularly in viscoelastic damping regimes where convergence becomes prohibitively slow.
AI.method: Introduce a more general transmission operator with two free parameters for the one-dimensional damped wave equation. Use frequency-domain analysis to derive explicit expression for convergence factor. Propose and compare two optimization strategies (L-infinity and L-2 minimization) for determining optimal transmission parameters.
AI.result: Numerical experiments demonstrate that the optimized approach significantly accelerates convergence compared to standard absorbing conditions, especially for viscoelastic damping cases. The method provides computationally efficient alternative to exhaustive parameter search while maintaining robust performance across different damping regimes.
AI.conclusion: The proposed optimization framework for transmission conditions effectively addresses the convergence limitations of Schwarz Waveform Relaxation for damped wave equations, offering substantial performance improvements over classical approaches.

title: Couette Taylor instabilities in the small-gap regime
summary:
The Couette-Taylor instability occurs in a viscous fluid confined between two coaxial rotating cylinders. When the Taylor number surpasses a critical value, the stable Couette flow destabilizes, giving way to steady Taylor vortices. As the Taylor number increases further, these vortices themselves become unstable, transitioning into wavy Taylor vortices.
  In this article, we focus on the small-gap limit, where the ratio of the cylinder radii approaches unity and the rotation rates of the cylinders are nearly identical. We provide a rigorous proof of the existence of a critical Taylor number $T_c$, at which the Couette flow loses stability.
  For Taylor numbers just above $T_c$, under fixed axial periodicity, the solutions to the limiting Navier-Stokes system are governed by a Ginzburg-Landau-type partial differential equation. Beyond the classical Taylor vortex flow, we demonstrate that a two-parameter family of solutions emerges at criticality for $T>T_c$. This family includes not only wavy vortices but also a variety of other exotic flow patterns, all of which remain steady in the frame rotating at the average angular velocity of the cylinders.
