AI.tldr: Rigorous proof of critical Taylor number for Couette-Taylor instability in small-gap limit, showing solutions governed by Ginzburg-Landau equation and emergence of exotic flow patterns beyond Taylor vortices.
AI.motivation: To provide rigorous mathematical analysis of the Couette-Taylor instability in the small-gap limit, where cylinder radii approach unity and rotation rates are nearly identical, establishing existence of critical Taylor number and characterizing flow patterns beyond instability.
AI.method: Mathematical analysis using limiting Navier-Stokes system in small-gap approximation, proving existence of critical Taylor number T_c, and deriving Ginzburg-Landau-type PDE governing solutions near criticality. Analysis of solution families emerging for T > T_c.
AI.result: Proved existence of critical Taylor number T_c where Couette flow loses stability. Showed solutions near T_c governed by Ginzburg-Landau equation. Demonstrated emergence of two-parameter family of solutions including wavy vortices and exotic flow patterns that remain steady in rotating frame.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides rigorous mathematical foundation for Couette-Taylor instability in small-gap limit, establishing critical Taylor number and characterizing rich variety of flow patterns beyond classical Taylor vortices, including wavy vortices and other exotic steady patterns in rotating frame.

title: In-Situ Inverse Design of a Plasma Metamaterial Beam Steering Device
summary: Inverse design is a commonly used methodology for creating devices that manipulate electromagnetic (EM) waves by algorithmically modifying device parameters to achieve a desired functionality. Utilizing plasma, a dynamically tunable medium, allows the optimization of the design process to be conducted directly on the experimental hardware (in-situ). A key advantage of this method is the creation of devices that are inherently switchable and dynamically reconfigurable. Bayesian optimization is used to tune the plasma density of 91 independent discharges that make up a plasma metamaterial (PMM) device to steer incoming EM waves to desired exit waveguides. Measurements were conducted in an automated loop where a vector network analyzer records the PMM transmission characteristics for each device setting. By relying only on measured scattering parameters, this gradient-free approach is robust to experimental drift and noise and does not require complex full-wave models. Significant performance improvements over traditional simulation-based (in-silico) inverse design are demonstrated, with in-situ Bayesian optimization achieving up to 10,000x higher isolation between ports than the best in-silico design at the same target frequency. This work also presents guidelines for applying Bayesian optimization to noisy, high-dimensional physical systems.

AI.tldr: In-situ Bayesian optimization of plasma metamaterials achieves 10,000x better port isolation than simulation-based inverse design by directly tuning 91 plasma discharges on experimental hardware.
AI.motivation: Traditional simulation-based inverse design for electromagnetic devices has limitations in handling experimental noise, drift, and dynamic reconfigurability. Plasma offers tunability but requires optimization methods robust to experimental conditions.
AI.method: Bayesian optimization is applied in-situ to tune plasma density of 91 independent discharges in a plasma metamaterial device. Automated measurements using a vector network analyzer record transmission characteristics, relying only on measured scattering parameters without complex full-wave models.
AI.result: In-situ Bayesian optimization achieves up to 10,000x higher isolation between ports than the best simulation-based (in-silico) inverse design at the same target frequency. The method is robust to experimental drift and noise.
AI.conclusion: In-situ Bayesian optimization with plasma metamaterials enables superior performance over traditional simulation-based approaches, creating inherently switchable and reconfigurable devices while providing guidelines for applying Bayesian optimization to noisy, high-dimensional physical systems.

title: Parareal algorithm for coupled elliptic-parabolic problems
summary: We present a convergence analysis of the parallel-in-time integration method known as the Parareal algorithm for degenerate differential-algebraic systems arising from quasi-static Biot models, which govern coupled flow and deformation in porous media. The underlying system exhibits a saddle-point structure and degeneracy due to the quasi-static assumption. We extend the Parareal algorithm to this setting and propose three coarse propagators: monolithic, fixed-stress, and multirate fixed-stress schemes. For each, we derive sufficient conditions for convergence and establish explicit time step restrictions that guarantee contractivity of the iteration matrix. Numerical experiments show computational savings accrued by using a parareal solver in multiphysics simulations involving poroelasticity and other coupled systems.

AI.tldr: Convergence analysis of Parareal algorithm for degenerate differential-algebraic systems from quasi-static Biot models, with three coarse propagator schemes and explicit convergence conditions.
AI.motivation: To analyze the convergence of parallel-in-time (Parareal) methods for degenerate differential-algebraic systems arising from quasi-static Biot models, which are important for simulating coupled flow and deformation in porous media but present challenges due to saddle-point structure and degeneracy.
AI.method: Extend Parareal algorithm to degenerate differential-algebraic systems and propose three coarse propagators: monolithic, fixed-stress, and multirate fixed-stress schemes. Derive sufficient convergence conditions and explicit time step restrictions that guarantee contractivity of the iteration matrix.
AI.result: Established convergence conditions for Parareal algorithm with three different coarse propagators for quasi-static Biot models. Numerical experiments demonstrate computational savings when using parareal solver in multiphysics simulations involving poroelasticity and other coupled systems.
AI.conclusion: The Parareal algorithm can be successfully extended to degenerate differential-algebraic systems from quasi-static Biot models with appropriate coarse propagators, providing computational savings for multiphysics simulations through parallel-in-time integration.

title: The Nonlocal-to-Local Limit for the Inviscid Leray-α Equations
summary: We consider the inviscid Leray-$α$ equations - an inviscid nonlocal regularisation of the Euler equations. In the first part, we prove the convergence of strong solutions of the Leray-$α$ equations to strong solutions of the Euler equations in $H^s(\mathbb{R}^d)$ for $s>d/2 +1 $, $d\in \{2,3\}$, for a large class of regularising kernels. In the second part, we consider weak solutions on a bounded domain with a local scaling property far away from the boundary. The scaling relates to second-order structure functions from turbulence theory and does not imply regularity. Nonetheless, under these assumptions, the weak solutions converge to (possibly wild) weak solutions of Euler in $L^2$ for almost every $t$.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes convergence properties of solutions to inviscid Leray-α equations (nonlocal regularization of Euler equations) to Euler solutions under different regularity assumptions.
AI.motivation: To understand how nonlocal regularizations of the Euler equations behave in the limit as the regularization parameter vanishes, particularly in relation to turbulence theory and structure functions.
AI.method: Two-part analysis: 1) Strong convergence in Sobolev spaces H^s for s > d/2+1 using analytical methods; 2) Weak convergence on bounded domains with local scaling properties related to turbulence structure functions.
AI.result: 1) Strong solutions of Leray-α converge to strong Euler solutions in H^s for s > d/2+1; 2) Weak solutions with scaling properties converge to (possibly wild) weak Euler solutions in L^2 for almost every t.
AI.conclusion: The Leray-α regularization provides a meaningful approximation to Euler equations, with strong convergence under high regularity and weak convergence under turbulence-relevant scaling assumptions, potentially capturing wild weak solutions.

title: Dielectric formalism of the 2D uniform electron gas at finite temperatures
summary: We present a comprehensive analysis of the two-dimensional uniform electron gas (2D-UEG or more commonly 2DEG) at finite temperature, spanning a broad range of densities / coupling strengths ($0.01\le{r}_s\le20$) and temperatures / degeneracy parameters ($0.01\leΘ= k_B T/E_F \le 10$). Within the self-consistent dielectric formalism, we construct two-dimensional versions of the Singwi-Tosi-Land-Sjölander (STLS) and hypernetted-chain (HNC) approximation based schemes. We benchmark the accuracy of the STLS and the HNC schemes against new state-of-the-art path-integral Monte Carlo data. We also report structural and thermodynamic properties across the full $(r_s,Θ)$ phase diagram domain studied, identify regimes in which these schemes remain quantitatively reliable, and provide an accurate parametrization of the exchange--correlation free energy of the finite-temperature 2DEG.

AI.tldr: The paper analyzes the 2D uniform electron gas at finite temperature using dielectric formalism approaches (STLS and HNC) and benchmarks them against path-integral Monte Carlo data, providing accurate parametrization of exchange-correlation free energy.
AI.motivation: To provide a comprehensive analysis of the 2D uniform electron gas across a wide range of densities and temperatures, addressing the need for accurate theoretical frameworks for this important quantum system at finite temperature.
AI.method: Developed two-dimensional versions of the Singwi-Tosi-Land-Sjölander (STLS) and hypernetted-chain (HNC) approximation schemes within the self-consistent dielectric formalism, and benchmarked them against new state-of-the-art path-integral Monte Carlo data.
AI.result: Reported structural and thermodynamic properties across the full (r_s, Θ) phase diagram domain (0.01 ≤ r_s ≤ 20, 0.01 ≤ Θ ≤ 10), identified regimes where STLS and HNC schemes remain quantitatively reliable, and provided accurate parametrization of the exchange-correlation free energy.
AI.conclusion: The study provides comprehensive benchmarks and accurate parametrizations for the finite-temperature 2D electron gas, establishing the reliability ranges of STLS and HNC approaches and offering valuable reference data for future research in this field.

title: Contour-integral based quantum eigenvalue transformation: analysis and applications
summary: Eigenvalue transformations appear ubiquitously in scientific computation, ranging from matrix polynomials to differential equations, and are beyond the reach of the quantum singular value transformation framework. In this work, we study the efficiency of quantum algorithms based on contour integral representation for eigenvalue transformations from both theoretical and practical aspects. Theoretically, we establish a complete complexity analysis of the contour integral approach proposed in [Takahira, Ohashi, Sogabe, and Usuda. Quant. Inf. Comput., 22, 11\&12, 965--979 (2021)]. Moreover, we combine the contour integral approach and the sampling-based linear combination of unitaries to propose a quantum algorithm for estimating observables of eigenvalue transformations using only $3$ additional qubits. Practically, we design contour integral based quantum algorithms for Hamiltonian simulation, matrix polynomials, and solving linear ordinary differential equations, and show that the contour integral algorithm can outperform all the existing quantum algorithms in the case of solving asymptotically stable differential equations.

AI.tldr: Quantum algorithm using contour integrals for eigenvalue transformations outperforms existing methods for certain differential equations.
AI.motivation: Eigenvalue transformations are fundamental in scientific computing but cannot be handled by quantum singular value transformation; need efficient quantum algorithms for these operations.
AI.method: Uses contour integral representation combined with sampling-based linear combination of unitaries; requires only 3 additional qubits for observable estimation.
AI.result: Complete complexity analysis of contour integral approach; new algorithm outperforms all existing quantum algorithms for solving asymptotically stable differential equations.
AI.conclusion: Contour integral approach provides practical quantum advantage for eigenvalue transformations, especially for differential equations, with minimal qubit overhead.

title: Mild Solutions for Time--Fractional Stochastic Nonlocal Diffusion Equations
summary:
We study a time--space nonlocal diffusion equation driven by additive time--space white noise, where the time derivative is the Caputo derivative of order $α\in(0,2)$. The model couples local diffusion with a nonlocal convolution operator generated by a radial probability density, thus incorporating memory effects and long-range spatial interactions.
  For Dirac initial data, we derive an explicit solution formula in the space of tempered distributions, decomposing the solution into a deterministic part and a stochastic convolution kernel expressed through Mittag--Leffler functions. Our main contribution is a sharp characterization of the existence of mild solutions in terms of $α$, the spatial dimension $N$, and the coefficients of the local and nonlocal diffusion terms. In particular, when the Laplacian term is absent, no mild solution exists, whereas for $λ>0$ the admissible regimes depend critically on $(α,N)$, extending and sharpening the known results for purely local fractional stochastic heat equations. Numerical simulations illustrate the evolution of the mean and variance and emphasize subdiffusive spreading and memory effects.

AI.tldr: The paper studies a time-space nonlocal diffusion equation with Caputo time derivative and additive white noise, deriving explicit solutions and characterizing existence conditions based on parameters α, N, and diffusion coefficients.
AI.motivation: To understand stochastic processes with memory effects and long-range spatial interactions, combining local diffusion with nonlocal convolution operators driven by white noise, which models complex phenomena in physics and biology.
AI.method: Analyzes a time-space nonlocal diffusion equation with Caputo derivative, derives explicit solution formula for Dirac initial data using tempered distributions, decomposes solution into deterministic and stochastic parts with Mittag-Leffler functions.
AI.result: Obtains sharp characterization of mild solution existence: no solution exists without Laplacian term; for λ>0, admissible regimes depend critically on (α,N), extending known results for local fractional stochastic heat equations. Numerical simulations show subdiffusive spreading and memory effects.
AI.conclusion: The interplay between time fractional derivative, spatial nonlocality, and white noise leads to rich solution behavior with existence conditions determined by parameter combinations, providing insights into stochastic processes with memory and long-range interactions.

title: Ab initio path-integral Monte Carlo results for the one-particle spectral function of the warm dense electron gas
summary: We compute quasi-exact \emph{ab initio} path-integral Monte Carlo results for the Matsubara Green's function of the uniform electron gas (UEG) at finite temperature over a broad range of coupling strengths ($r_s=1,\dots,10)$. This allows us to present approximation-free results for the static self-energy $Σ_\infty(p)$ and spectral function $A(p,ω)$, and to benchmark previous approximate results for the UEG. In addition, our work opens up intriguing avenues to study the single-particle spectrum and density of states of real warm dense matter systems based on truly first principles.

AI.tldr: First-principles path-integral Monte Carlo calculations of Matsubara Green's function for uniform electron gas at finite temperature across coupling strengths rs=1-10, providing benchmark results for self-energy and spectral function.
AI.motivation: To provide approximation-free, quasi-exact ab initio results for the uniform electron gas at finite temperature, enabling accurate benchmarking of previous approximate methods and opening pathways to study real warm dense matter systems from first principles.
AI.method: Path-integral Monte Carlo calculations for the Matsubara Green's function of the uniform electron gas at finite temperature across a range of coupling strengths (rs=1 to 10).
AI.result: Computed quasi-exact ab initio results for the static self-energy Σ∞(p) and spectral function A(p,ω), providing benchmark data for previous approximate UEG results.
AI.conclusion: The work establishes reliable first-principles results for the UEG that can serve as benchmarks and opens new avenues for studying single-particle spectra and density of states in real warm dense matter systems.

title: All-Pass Fractional OPF: A Solver-Friendly, Physics-Preserving Approximation of AC OPF
summary: This paper presents a fractional approximation of the AC optimal power flow (AC OPF) problem based on an all-pass approximation of the exponential power flow kernel. The classical AC OPF relies on trigonometric coupling between bus voltage phasors, which yields a nonconvex program with oscillatory derivatives that can slow, or in some cases destabilize, interior-point methods. We replace the trigonometric terms with an all-pass fractional (APF) approximation whose real and imaginary components act as smooth surrogates for the cosine and sine functions, and we introduce a pre-rotation to shift the argument of the approximation toward its most accurate region, ensuring that the reformulated power flow model preserves physical loss behavior, maintains the symmetry of the classical kernels, and improves the conditioning of the Jacobian and Hessian matrices. The proposed APF OPF formulation remains nonconvex, as in the classical model, but it eliminates trigonometric evaluations and empirically produces larger and more stable Newton steps under standard interior-point solvers. Numerical results on more than 25 IEEE and PGLib test systems ranging from 9 to 10{,}000 buses demonstrate that the APF OPF model achieves solutions with accuracy comparable to that of the classical formulation while reducing solver times, indicating a more solver-friendly nonconvex representation of AC OPF. All code, functions, verification scripts, and generated results are publicly available on \href{https://github.com/LSU-RAISE-LAB/APF-OPF}{GitHub}, along with a README describing how to run and reproduce the experiments.

AI.tldr: The paper presents a fractional approximation of AC optimal power flow that replaces trigonometric terms with an all-pass fractional approximation, improving solver performance while maintaining accuracy.
AI.motivation: Classical AC OPF uses trigonometric coupling between bus voltage phasors, creating a nonconvex program with oscillatory derivatives that can slow or destabilize interior-point methods.
AI.method: Replace trigonometric terms with an all-pass fractional (APF) approximation whose real/imaginary components act as smooth surrogates for cosine/sine functions, with pre-rotation to shift arguments to more accurate regions while preserving physical loss behavior and kernel symmetry.
AI.result: APF OPF achieves solutions with accuracy comparable to classical formulation while reducing solver times, with numerical results on 25+ IEEE/PGLib test systems (9-10,000 buses) showing larger, more stable Newton steps under interior-point solvers.
AI.conclusion: The APF OPF formulation eliminates trigonometric evaluations and provides a more solver-friendly nonconvex representation of AC OPF while maintaining physical accuracy, with all code publicly available.

title: Helmholtz transmission problem and intrinsic impedance scattering problem on extension domains
summary: We consider a transmission problem for the Helmholtz equation across the boundary of an extension domain. A such boundary can be Lipschitz, fractal, or of varying Hausdorff dimension for instance. We generalise the notions of layer potential and Neumann-Poincar{é} operators, and of Calder{ó}n projectors in that context. Those boundary operators allow to connect the transmission problem (on the whole space) to one-sided problems -- notably, scattering problems -- with Dirichlet, Neumann and Robin boundary conditions. Since an extension domain needs no specific boundary measure, the Robin (impedance) condition is not understood in a boundary L^2-type space, rather by duality on the trace space itself. We discuss the well-posedness of the impedance scattering problem in that framework and compare to the classical L^2 setting. Our analysis allows to generalise optimisation results for acoustic scattering when the obstacle is an extension domain in any dimension.

AI.tldr: Generalization of layer potentials, Neumann-Poincaré operators, and Calderón projectors for Helmholtz transmission problems across boundaries of extension domains (Lipschitz, fractal, varying dimension).
AI.motivation: To extend scattering theory and boundary operator methods to more general domains beyond smooth boundaries, particularly extension domains with irregular boundaries like fractals or varying Hausdorff dimension.
AI.method: Generalize layer potentials, Neumann-Poincaré operators, and Calderón projectors for extension domains. Reformulate Robin boundary conditions via duality on trace spaces rather than L² boundary spaces. Connect transmission problems to one-sided scattering problems with Dirichlet, Neumann, and Robin conditions.
AI.result: Established framework for well-posedness of impedance scattering problems on extension domains. Generalized optimization results for acoustic scattering when obstacles are extension domains in any dimension.
AI.conclusion: Successfully extended classical scattering theory to irregular boundaries using functional analysis on trace spaces, enabling scattering analysis on fractals and other extension domains without requiring specific boundary measures.

title: Large Data Limits of Laplace Learning for Gaussian Measure Data in Infinite Dimensions
summary: Laplace learning is a semi-supervised method, a solution for finding missing labels from a partially labeled dataset utilizing the geometry given by the unlabeled data points. The method minimizes a Dirichlet energy defined on a (discrete) graph constructed from the full dataset. In finite dimensions the asymptotics in the large (unlabeled) data limit are well understood with convergence from the graph setting to a continuum Sobolev semi-norm weighted by the Lebesgue density of the data-generating measure. The lack of the Lebesgue measure on infinite-dimensional spaces requires rethinking the analysis if the data aren't finite-dimensional. In this paper we make a first step in this direction by analyzing the setting when the data are generated by a Gaussian measure on a Hilbert space and proving pointwise convergence of the graph Dirichlet energy.

AI.tldr: Analysis of Laplace learning convergence for infinite-dimensional Gaussian data in Hilbert spaces, extending finite-dimensional results.
AI.motivation: Laplace learning works well for finite-dimensional data with known asymptotics, but lacks analysis for infinite-dimensional data where Lebesgue measure doesn't exist, requiring new theoretical foundations.
AI.method: Analyze Laplace learning when data are generated by a Gaussian measure on a Hilbert space, proving pointwise convergence of the graph Dirichlet energy to a continuum limit.
AI.result: Established pointwise convergence results for the graph Dirichlet energy in infinite-dimensional settings with Gaussian data, providing first theoretical guarantees beyond finite dimensions.
AI.conclusion: Successfully extended Laplace learning analysis to infinite-dimensional Hilbert spaces with Gaussian measures, laying groundwork for understanding semi-supervised learning in high-dimensional settings.

title: Note on the multiplicity of solutions for nonlinear scalar field equations with a critical inverse-square potential
summary: We are interested in the multiplicity of solutions to the following scalar field equation $$ -Δu - \frac{(N-2)^2}{4|x|^2} u = g(u), \quad \mbox{in } \mathbb{R}^N \setminus \{0\}. $$ We establish the existence of infinitely many radial and non-radial solutions.

AI.tldr: The paper establishes existence of infinitely many radial and non-radial solutions to a scalar field equation with Hardy potential in ℝᴺ\{0}.
AI.motivation: The motivation is to study multiplicity of solutions for nonlinear elliptic equations with singular Hardy-type potentials, which arise in various physical contexts and present mathematical challenges due to the singular coefficient.
AI.method: The authors likely use variational methods, critical point theory, and symmetry-breaking techniques to establish existence of both radial and non-radial solutions. Methods may include mountain pass theorem, symmetric criticality principle, and concentration-compactness arguments.
AI.result: The main result proves the existence of infinitely many radial solutions and infinitely many non-radial solutions to the scalar field equation with Hardy potential in ℝᴺ\{0}.
AI.conclusion: The equation admits rich solution structure with both radial symmetry and symmetry-breaking solutions, demonstrating that the Hardy potential does not prevent multiplicity of solutions despite its singular nature.

title: On the existence of Ulanowicz's optimal structural resilience in complex networks
summary: This study investigates the mathematical existence and asymptotic properties of Ulanowicz's structural resilience in complex systems such as supply chain networks. While ecological evidence suggests that sustainable systems gravitate toward an optimal state at $α= 1/\mathrm{e}$, the universality of this configuration in generalized networks remains theoretically unverified. We prove that while optimal resilience is unattainable in two-node networks due to structural over-determinacy, it exists for any directed graph with $N_\mathcal{V} \geq 3$. By constructing a symmetric network model with three types of link weights $(x, y, z)$ and uniform marginal distributions, we derive the governing equations for the optimal resilience configuration. Our analytical and numerical results reveal that as the network size $N_\mathcal{V}$ increases, the link weights required to maintain optimal resilience exhibit a power-law scaling behavior: the adjacent links scale as $O(N_\mathcal{V}^{-1})$, while the non-adjacent links scale as $O(N_\mathcal{V}^{-2})$, both accompanied by specific logarithmic corrections. This work establishes a rigorous mathematical foundation for the optimal resilience framework and provides a unified perspective on how entropy-based principles govern the robustness and evolution of large-scale complex networks, which may offer quantitative guidance for designing large-scale networked systems under robustness constraints.

AI.tldr: Proves mathematical existence and scaling properties of optimal structural resilience in complex networks, showing it's unattainable in 2-node networks but exists for N≥3, with link weights following power-law scaling with network size.
AI.motivation: While ecological evidence suggests sustainable systems gravitate toward optimal resilience at α=1/e, the universality of this configuration in generalized networks remains theoretically unverified. The study aims to establish rigorous mathematical foundations for Ulanowicz's structural resilience framework in complex systems.
AI.method: Constructs symmetric network model with three types of link weights (x, y, z) and uniform marginal distributions. Derives governing equations for optimal resilience configuration and analyzes both analytically and numerically. Proves existence theorems for different network sizes.
AI.result: Optimal resilience is unattainable in two-node networks due to structural over-determinacy but exists for any directed graph with N≥3. As network size increases, link weights exhibit power-law scaling: adjacent links scale as O(N⁻¹) and non-adjacent links scale as O(N⁻²), both with logarithmic corrections.
AI.conclusion: Establishes rigorous mathematical foundation for optimal resilience framework and provides unified perspective on how entropy-based principles govern robustness and evolution of large-scale complex networks. Offers quantitative guidance for designing large-scale networked systems under robustness constraints.

title: On a Class of Global Solutions to 3D Free-Boundary Relativistic Euler Equations with a Physical Vacuum Boundary
summary: We consider the free-boundary relativistic Euler equations in Minkowski spacetime $\mathbb{M}^{1+3}$ equipped with a physical vacuum boundary, which models the motion of a relativistic gas. We concern ourselves with the family of isentropic, barotropic, and polytropic gas, with an equation of state $p = ρ^{1+κ}, κ\in (0,\frac23]$. We construct an open class of initial data that launches future-global solutions. Such solutions are spherically symmetric, have small initial density, and expand asymptotically linearly in time. In particular, the asymptotic rate of expansion is allowed to be arbitrarily close to the speed of light. Therefore, our main result is far from a perturbation of existing results concerning the classical isentropic Euler counterparts.

AI.tldr: Global solutions for relativistic Euler equations with physical vacuum boundary for polytropic gases, showing expansion near light speed.
AI.motivation: To study the free-boundary relativistic Euler equations in Minkowski spacetime modeling relativistic gas motion with physical vacuum boundary, extending beyond classical Euler results.
AI.method: Construct open class of spherically symmetric initial data with small initial density for isentropic, barotropic, polytropic gases (p = ρ^{1+κ}, κ∈(0,2/3]).
AI.result: Future-global solutions exist that expand asymptotically linearly in time, with expansion rates arbitrarily close to speed of light, far from classical Euler perturbations.
AI.conclusion: Establishes existence of global solutions for relativistic gas with physical vacuum boundary that can expand near light speed, significantly extending classical results.

title: Gauge transform for the Korteweg-de Vries equation and well-posedness below the $H^{-1}$-scale
summary: We propose a new formulation of the Korteweg-de Vries equation (KdV) on the real line, via a gauge transform. While KdV and the gauged equation are equivalent for smooth solutions, the latter is better behaved at low regularity in Fourier-Lebesgue spaces. In particular, the admissible regularities go beyond the $H^{-1}$-scale, which is a well-known threshold for KdV. As a byproduct, by reversing the gauge transform, we are able to improve on the known theory for KdV and derive sharp local well-posedness in Fourier-Lebesgue spaces with large integrability exponent. Our strategy is based on an infinite normal form reduction and Fourier restriction estimates, together with a thorough exploitation of algebraic cancellations. Additionally, our method is totally independent of the KdV completely integrable structure, and extends to other non-integrable models with quadratic nonlinearities.

AI.tldr: The paper introduces a gauge-transformed formulation of KdV that enables improved well-posedness results in low-regularity Fourier-Lebesgue spaces beyond the H⁻¹ threshold.
AI.motivation: The standard KdV equation faces limitations in low-regularity settings, particularly at the H⁻¹ threshold. The authors aim to develop a formulation that overcomes these limitations and extends to non-integrable models.
AI.method: A gauge transformation is applied to KdV, creating an equivalent but better-behaved equation. The analysis uses infinite normal form reduction, Fourier restriction estimates, and careful exploitation of algebraic cancellations.
AI.result: The gauged formulation achieves improved well-posedness in Fourier-Lebesgue spaces beyond the H⁻¹ scale. By reversing the gauge transform, sharp local well-posedness is established for KdV in spaces with large integrability exponents.
AI.conclusion: The gauge transform approach successfully extends low-regularity theory for KdV and applies to other non-integrable quadratic models, independent of KdV's integrable structure.

title: Partial Hölder regularity for fully nonlinear nonlocal parabolic equations with integrable kernels
summary: In this work, we consider solutions to (fully nonlinear) parabolic integro-differential equations with integrable interaction kernels. A typical equation would be that obtained by starting with, for $s\in(0,1)$, the $s$-fractional heat equation, but replacing the interaction kernel in the integro-differential term with one which has been truncated, for $ρ>0$, at the value $ρ^{-d-2s}$, hence integrable. We show that solutions to these equations have a partial regularity estimate which captures differences of the solution up to the scale at which the kernel has a truncation in its singularity. The estimates we provide are robust with respect to the truncation parameter, and they include the existing results for the original operators without truncation. There are some earlier results for linear and elliptic cases of this situation of integrable interaction kernels, and so our work is a generalization of those to the nonlinear and parabolic setting.

AI.tldr: The paper establishes partial regularity estimates for solutions to fully nonlinear parabolic integro-differential equations with integrable interaction kernels, generalizing previous linear/elliptic results to nonlinear/parabolic settings.
AI.motivation: To study parabolic integro-differential equations with truncated, integrable kernels (like truncated fractional heat equations) and develop regularity estimates that work robustly across truncation scales, including the non-truncated case.
AI.method: Analyzes solutions to fully nonlinear parabolic integro-differential equations with integrable interaction kernels, focusing on establishing partial regularity estimates that capture solution differences up to the truncation scale of the kernel's singularity.
AI.result: Shows that solutions have partial regularity estimates robust with respect to truncation parameters, generalizing previous linear/elliptic results to nonlinear/parabolic settings, and includes the non-truncated case as a special instance.
AI.conclusion: The paper successfully extends regularity theory to nonlinear parabolic integro-differential equations with integrable kernels, providing estimates that work uniformly across truncation scales and recover known results for non-truncated operators.

title: Traveling waves for bistable reaction-diffusion-convection equations with discontinuous density-dependent coefficients
summary: Continuing our previous study \cite{DJKZ} on the monostable reaction-diffusion-convection equation, we analyze the bistable case under weak regularity assumptions. Our approach applies monostable results on the subintervals where the reaction term $g$ has constant sign, thereby establishing both existence and nonexistence of bistable traveling wave solutions. We extend the results of \cite{MMM04}, obtained for $p=2$ under higher regularity assumptions ($d \in C^1[0,1]$, $g,h \in C[0,1]$), to the $p$-Laplacian with $p>1$ in our weak regularity setting.

AI.tldr: Extends previous monostable analysis to bistable reaction-diffusion-convection equations with p-Laplacian under weak regularity assumptions, establishing existence/nonexistence of traveling waves.
AI.motivation: To extend previous monostable results to the bistable case with weaker regularity assumptions than existing literature, and generalize from p=2 to p-Laplacian with p>1.
AI.method: Applies monostable results from previous study on subintervals where the reaction term has constant sign, allowing analysis of bistable traveling wave solutions under weak regularity conditions.
AI.result: Establishes both existence and nonexistence of bistable traveling wave solutions for p-Laplacian equations with p>1 under weak regularity assumptions, extending previous results.
AI.conclusion: Successfully generalizes bistable traveling wave analysis to p-Laplacian equations with weak regularity, improving upon previous work that required higher regularity assumptions for p=2 case.

title: A New Measure of Coarseness for Solutions to Cahn--Hilliard Equations
comment: 33 pages, 14 figures. arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap with arXiv:2405.11709
summary: We introduce a new measure of coarseness for characterizing phase separation processes such as those described by Cahn--Hilliard equations. An advantage of our measure is that it remains consistent throughout the evolution, including for solutions with no periodic structure. We use our measure to compare two previous models of coarsening dynamics with numerically generated dynamics, providing the first direct check that we are aware of for the efficacy of these methods.

title: Variational and Quasi-variational solutions to thick flows

AI.tldr: The paper formulates thick fluid flow as variational and quasi-variational inequalities with deformation rate constraints, proving existence/uniqueness for viscous (Navier-Stokes) and inviscid (Euler) cases, then extends to variable thresholds.

title: De Giorgi's regularity theory for elliptic, parabolic and kinetic equations

summary: This book presents a comprehensive regularity theory for solutions of elliptic, parabolic, and kinetic equations. The foundation of this theory was laid by E. De Giorgi's groundbreaking resolution of Hilbert's nineteenth problem in 1956. The innovative tools he developed to tackle this problem proved to be remarkably versatile. In 1957, just one year later, J. Nash independently developed analogous techniques for parabolic equations, concurrently with De Giorgi's research. By the year 2000, these techniques had been extended to address elliptic and parabolic equations featuring integral diffusion, such as the fractional Laplacian. More recently, the theory has evolved to encompass kinetic equations, accommodating both local and integral diffusions. This book aims to present these results in a unified and coherent manner, beginning with the classical elliptic framework and progressing through to the most recent advancements in kinetic equations.

AI.tldr: Comprehensive regularity theory for elliptic, parabolic, and kinetic equations, tracing development from De Giorgi's 1956 breakthrough through modern extensions to fractional and kinetic equations.
AI.motivation: To present a unified regularity theory that connects classical elliptic results with modern extensions to parabolic, fractional diffusion, and kinetic equations, showing the evolution and versatility of De Giorgi's foundational techniques.
AI.method: Builds on De Giorgi's pioneering methods for elliptic equations (1956), Nash's independent parabolic extensions (1957), subsequent generalizations to fractional Laplacian equations (by 2000), and recent extensions to kinetic equations with both local and integral diffusions.
AI.result: A comprehensive, unified presentation of regularity theory spanning from classical elliptic equations to modern kinetic equations, demonstrating the remarkable versatility and evolution of the foundational techniques over decades.
AI.conclusion: The book successfully unifies decades of regularity theory development, showing how De Giorgi's original breakthrough techniques have proven remarkably adaptable and have evolved to address increasingly complex equations including modern kinetic equations with various diffusion types.

title: Non-Hydrodynamic Solutions to the linear Density-dependent BGK equation
summary: We prove the existence of non-hydrodynamic solutions to the linear density-dependent BGK equation in $d$ dimensions. Specifically, we show the existence of an initial condition for any Knudsen number $τ$ for which the dissipation rate of the macroscopic mass density diverges $\sim 1/τ$. Our results rely on a detailed spectral analysis of the linear BGK operator, an explicit solution formula for the time-dependent problem using a combination of Fourier series with the Laplace transform and subsequent contour integration arguments from complex analysis.

AI.tldr: Existence of non-hydrodynamic solutions to linear density-dependent BGK equation with diverging dissipation rate
AI.motivation: To understand the behavior of solutions to the BGK equation beyond hydrodynamic regimes, particularly examining cases where dissipation rates diverge
AI.method: Detailed spectral analysis of linear BGK operator, explicit solution formula using Fourier series with Laplace transform, and contour integration arguments from complex analysis
AI.result: Proved existence of non-hydrodynamic solutions for any Knudsen number τ where dissipation rate of macroscopic mass density diverges ∼ 1/τ
AI.conclusion: Demonstrates pathological behavior in BGK equation with diverging dissipation rates, revealing limitations of hydrodynamic approximations

title: Topology optimization concerning the mass distribution via filtered gradient flows on the Wasserstein space
summary: In this article, we formulate topology optimization problems concerning the mass distribution as minimization problems for functionals on the Wasserstein space. We relax optimization problems regarding non-convex objective functions on the Wasserstein space by using the Neumann heat semigroup and prove the existence of minimizers of relaxed problems. Furthermore, we introduce the filtered Wasserstein gradient flow and derive the error estimate between the original Wasserstein gradient flow and the filtered one in terms of the Wasserstein distance. We also construct a candidate for the optimal mass distribution for a given fixed total mass and simultaneously obtain the shape of the material by the numerical calculation of filtered Wasserstein gradient flows.

AI.tldr: Topology optimization formulated as minimization on Wasserstein space using heat semigroup relaxation and filtered gradient flows with error estimates.
AI.motivation: To address topology optimization problems for mass distribution by formulating them as minimization problems on the Wasserstein space, which provides a mathematical framework for comparing probability distributions and mass distributions.
AI.method: 1) Formulate topology optimization as functional minimization on Wasserstein space; 2) Use Neumann heat semigroup to relax non-convex optimization problems; 3) Introduce filtered Wasserstein gradient flow; 4) Derive error estimates between original and filtered gradient flows; 5) Perform numerical calculations of filtered gradient flows.
AI.result: 1) Proved existence of minimizers for relaxed problems; 2) Derived error estimates between original and filtered Wasserstein gradient flows in terms of Wasserstein distance; 3) Constructed candidate optimal mass distributions and obtained material shapes through numerical calculations.
AI.conclusion: The paper successfully develops a mathematical framework for topology optimization using Wasserstein space, provides theoretical guarantees through existence proofs and error estimates, and demonstrates practical applicability through numerical implementation for determining optimal mass distributions and material shapes.

title: Learning PDE Solvers with Physics and Data: A Unifying View of Physics-Informed Neural Networks and Neural Operators
summary: Partial differential equations (PDEs) are central to scientific modeling. Modern workflows increasingly rely on learning-based components to support model reuse, inference, and integration across large computational processes. Despite the emergence of various physics-aware data-driven approaches, the field still lacks a unified perspective to uncover their relationships, limitations, and appropriate roles in scientific workflows. To this end, we propose a unifying perspective to place two dominant paradigms: Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) and Neural Operators (NOs), within a shared design space. We organize existing methods from three fundamental dimensions: what is learned, how physical structures are integrated into the learning process, and how the computational load is amortized across problem instances. In this way, many challenges can be best understood as consequences of these structural properties of learning PDEs. By analyzing advances through this unifying view, our survey aims to facilitate the development of reliable learning-based PDE solvers and catalyze a synthesis of physics and data.

AI.tldr: A unifying framework for physics-aware learning methods for PDEs, analyzing PINNs and neural operators through three dimensions: what is learned, how physics is integrated, and computational amortization.
AI.motivation: The field lacks a unified perspective to understand relationships, limitations, and appropriate roles of various physics-aware data-driven approaches in scientific workflows, despite their increasing importance in modern scientific modeling.
AI.method: Proposes a unifying perspective organized around three fundamental dimensions: 1) what is learned (model vs. solution), 2) how physical structures are integrated into learning (constraints vs. inductive biases), and 3) how computational load is amortized across problem instances.
AI.result: Provides a shared design space that places Physics-Informed Neural Networks (PINNs) and Neural Operators (NOs) within a unified framework, enabling systematic analysis of existing methods and their structural properties.
AI.conclusion: This unifying view helps understand challenges as consequences of structural properties of learning PDEs, aims to facilitate development of reliable learning-based PDE solvers, and catalyzes synthesis of physics and data in scientific workflows.

title: Sobolev multipliers and fractional Gaussian fields on Lipschitz boundaries with applications to deterministic and random acoustic systems
summary: Motivated by Applied Physics and Photonics studies of random resonators, we study in the stochastic part of this paper random acoustic operators in non-smooth bounded domains $G \subset \mathbb{R}^d$ and introduce m-dissipative impedance boundary conditions containing fractional Gaussian fields (FGFs). The deterministic part of the paper constructs and studies the spaces of pointwise multipliers on Lipschitz continuous boundaries $\partial G$, as well as the spaces of Sobolev (distribution-type) multipliers on boundaries $\partial G$ of better regularity. These multipliers are used as generalized impedance coefficients $ζ(x)$, $x \in \partial G$, in impedance boundary conditions accompanying the first order acoustic system. The main efforts are aimed on the m-dissipativity of associated acoustic operators and the discreteness of the related spectra under weakest possible assumptions on the regularity of $ζ$. In order to connect the deterministic results with the randomization, we introduce FGFs on Lipschitz boundaries $\partial G$ and study their regularity. To this end, we prove that a rough Weyl-type asymptotics takes place for the Laplace-Beltrami eigenvalues on arbitrary compact boundary $\partial G$ of $C^{0,1}$-regularity.

AI.tldr: The paper studies random acoustic operators with m-dissipative impedance boundary conditions containing fractional Gaussian fields on non-smooth domains, connecting deterministic multiplier theory with stochastic analysis.
AI.motivation: Motivated by Applied Physics and Photonics studies of random resonators, the paper aims to analyze random acoustic operators in non-smooth bounded domains with generalized impedance boundary conditions.
AI.method: The deterministic part constructs spaces of pointwise and Sobolev multipliers on Lipschitz boundaries for impedance coefficients. The stochastic part introduces fractional Gaussian fields on Lipschitz boundaries and studies their regularity. The paper proves m-dissipativity of acoustic operators and discreteness of spectra under minimal regularity assumptions, and establishes rough Weyl-type asymptotics for Laplace-Beltrami eigenvalues on C^{0,1} boundaries.
AI.result: The paper establishes m-dissipativity of acoustic operators with generalized impedance boundary conditions, proves discreteness of spectra under weakest possible regularity assumptions, introduces FGFs on Lipschitz boundaries, and proves rough Weyl-type asymptotics for Laplace-Beltrami eigenvalues on arbitrary compact C^{0,1} boundaries.
AI.conclusion: The paper successfully connects deterministic multiplier theory with stochastic analysis, providing a rigorous framework for studying random acoustic operators with impedance boundary conditions on non-smooth domains, with applications to random resonator problems in physics and photonics.

title: Rate of convergence of random attractors towards deterministic singleton attractor for a class of non-Newtonian fluids of differential type
summary: In this article, we investigate the long-term dynamics of a class of two- and three-dimensional non-Newtonian fluids of differential type, known as third-grade fluids. We first show that when the external forcing is sufficiently small, the global attractor of the underlying system (which characterizes its asymptotic behavior) reduces to a single point. We then consider the system under stochastic perturbations, specifically infinite-dimensional additive white noise. In this random setting, we do not find conclusive evidence that the corresponding random attractor remains a single point, as in the deterministic case. However, we are able to estimate the rate at which the random attractor approaches the deterministic singleton attractor as the intensity of the stochastic noise tends to zero.

AI.tldr: Study of third-grade fluid dynamics shows deterministic system has single-point attractor for small forcing, but stochastic version's random attractor may not be singleton, though it approaches deterministic attractor as noise vanishes.
AI.motivation: To understand the asymptotic behavior of non-Newtonian third-grade fluids under both deterministic and stochastic perturbations, particularly how noise affects the attractor structure.
AI.method: Analyze long-term dynamics of two- and three-dimensional third-grade fluids using dynamical systems theory. First study deterministic case with small external forcing, then extend to stochastic setting with infinite-dimensional additive white noise.
AI.result: For deterministic system with small forcing, global attractor reduces to single point. Under stochastic perturbations, random attractor may not be singleton, but its approach to deterministic attractor as noise intensity → 0 can be estimated.
AI.conclusion: Stochastic perturbations fundamentally change attractor structure from deterministic singleton to potentially more complex random attractor, though convergence to deterministic limit as noise vanishes can be quantified.

title: Some reverse inequality in optimal mass transportation
summary: Controlling the $\mathcal W_\infty$ Wasserstein distance by the $\mathcal W_p$ Wasserstein distance is interesting both for theorical and numerical applications. A first paper on this problem was written several years ago [3]. Some year later [14] framed it in the same inequality for more general costs which increase with the distance. In this paper, we prove this type of inequality for optimal transport problems with pointwise cost which is a decreasing function of the distance. We show, in particular, that there is a general framework that encompasses all the cases above.

AI.tldr: The paper proves inequalities controlling the W∞ Wasserstein distance by Wp distances for optimal transport with decreasing cost functions of distance, unifying previous work.
AI.motivation: To establish connections between different Wasserstein distances (W∞ and Wp) for theoretical and numerical applications, extending previous work that focused on increasing cost functions to include decreasing cost functions.
AI.method: Develops a general mathematical framework for proving inequalities between Wasserstein distances, specifically focusing on optimal transport problems where the cost function decreases with distance, providing a unified approach that encompasses previous cases.
AI.result: Successfully proves the desired inequality for optimal transport with decreasing cost functions, demonstrating that the general framework covers all previous cases including those with increasing cost functions.
AI.conclusion: The paper provides a comprehensive framework for relating different Wasserstein distances, unifying previous results and extending them to include decreasing cost functions, which has implications for both theoretical analysis and numerical applications in optimal transport.
